developerResponse: {'id': 5789410, 'body': 'Thank you for your thoughtful review, CatLadyOnTheFarm. review:
Pretty cool app, but asking access to my iPhone‚Äôs health app to verify steps and only compute half or 1/3 of the actual steps taken registered by my iPhone is pointless. Is this not to give user sweatcoins? Why not use your app to piggyback onto the health app and use the data recorded on both apps (yours and iPhone) to verify so there‚Äôs no cheating? I have a 10 acre homestead and walk A LOT all day. Outdoors. When it‚Äôs very hot I switch my sleeping schedule to do chores throughout the night and sleep when it‚Äôs the hottest part of the day. 
My iPhone counted 11k steps in one day, Sweatcpins registered 4K.... 
the idea of the app is awesome to inventive people to stay moving, but you (developers) should be a bit more in tune with whatever app you request access to on our phones. 
Oh, and because I know I take thousands of steps every day, I opted for a system that charges me 20 sweatcoins a month, but if you‚Äôre not counting truly all the steps I take, I may just delete your app, because it feels like the ones whos cheating here is you... will keep it a little longer and see what happens. 
Understand that allowing you to track my location and access to my health data is not something I want you to have for free, like everything in this world, data mining comes with a price, and if you‚Äôre not offering your users a decent payout and registering ALL the steps I take, you may not get to keep my data... and that‚Äôs not my isolated opinion...

review: ok so sweatcoin is an interesting app. you really have to not delete the app if you want anything worth purchasing. i have joined in december of 2017, and i have around 1.8k coins. i am writing this review in april of 2019. first off is the purchase you can make with sweatcoin. the proportions really do not line up at all. for example, you can buy some fancy socks worth 15$ for 1.5k sweatcoin. now, you can also buy a jewelry subscription and a 21$ shopping credit for a mere 10 sweatcoin. the proportions rarely line up. sure, the developers can‚Äôt argue too much with their companies but still it should be slightly better. next, is the things you can buy. it‚Äôs all repetitive items and they are most of the time all discounts for items. idk about everyone else, but i want to buy stuff for free. no money involved PERIOD. too many of the free offers are MUCH too expensive and cost too much sweatcoin for one person no matter how much they walk. speaking of which, the step counter algorithm is god awful. sure, you don‚Äôt want people shaking their phones but COME ON. i have a fitbit and it tells be i walk around 8k steps everyday! sweatcoin on the other hand that only 1k of those 8k were actually real steps. at least let the algorithm be a little more generous here. now, you really want this app, just download it, forget about it, and check every week or so to see what offers are new. (please improve the algorithm and add in more free stuff)

review:
This app is somewhat motivating, but very frustrating. My biggest issue is their algorithm for step conversion‚Äîit‚Äôs wildly inaccurate and undercounts my steps by at least 50% every day. Today for example, I did my 20 minute daily boost - inside, on a treadmill, walking with my phone in my hand. I could literally see the steps ticking up in the app during this time, and before the boost ended, I had over 2000 steps in. Then, when the boost was complete and the steps were ‚Äúcalculated‚Äù, the app told me that I had somehow taken a measly 356 steps in that time! SECONDS before, it said I had taken 2000+. My Apple Watch and phone also said that I had taken over 2000 steps, and once I exited out of the boost, my total steps had increased by over 2000 as well. But for some reason, Sweat Coin decided that only a fraction of my steps actually counted. Seriously?! 

To make matters worse, I actually PAY for this app because I assumed that it would be the fastest way to get coins for the offers and products‚Ä¶since I‚Äôm constantly and consistently being inaccurately converted, though, it‚Äôs probably taking just as long as if it were accurately counting my steps without any ‚Äúboosts‚Äù or bonuses. I feel cheated and will definitely not be renewing my subscription. 

The rewards are fine. The app itself is attractive. I do find it motivating to try to increase my activity and distance. But omg, walking 15k steps in a day and only getting credit for 7k is just BAD.
title: Inaccurate step conversion

review: Sweat coin has a great idea but it isn‚Äôt being executed very well. First off the step counter is WAY off, all the time. I noticed from the beginning I was getting cheated out of at least 1000 steps a day, usually more. When you finally have generated enough steps to buy something your options are seriously limited. Most of them fall into health and fitness categories, which I don‚Äôt mind it would just be nice to have a bit more variety. Then after you get past the physical items they have a variety of coupons to offer in exchange for sweat coins. Please don‚Äôt buy coupons on this app, I promise you can get almost all of them from a different source without having to pay anything for them. A quick Google search will find the same coupon. I did that frequently and saved my sweat coins. I only was able to buy on thing with my sweat coins that I was interested in. In the end I ended up paying about $20 in shipping for the item. It was a bag of coffee and I was really hesitant to pay, but since I had already used my sweat coins I didn‚Äôt want to waste them. The app would also continuously crash on me as well. Ultimately I donated the rest of my sweat coins to charity, which I am willing to bet much of the money did not actually go to said charity. I have since deleted this app and I don‚Äôt see myself getting it again. If another app pops up following the same idea in a more honest way, I‚Äôll probably give it a try.
title: Not as great as promised

review: I downloaded the app a year ago. I wasn‚Äôt really benefiting from it and needed the extra space in my phone so I deleted it. I redownloaded the app a month ago in hopes that the app had improved and I noticed it had pretty decent reviews since I uninstalled it so I gave it another try. The app does not count all of your steps and it only works with your phone or an Apple Watch of certain versions. The app doesn‚Äôt allow you to use other smart watches even though my smart watch has all of the qualifications that the creators claim their app needs. I sent them a support problem ticket bringing up several issues to take into consideration and they sent me the generic answer on their forum about solving the problem instead of actually reading the ticket and sending a reply. I messaged them back asking them to read the ticket and to get back with me but after a week of waiting I got nothing. I sent another ticket and within 2 minutes got another generic answer to my problem that had nothing to do with what was actually on the ticket. I gave two stars because the idea behind the app is a good one but the app itself needs work, not to mention the customer support is tacky and useless if you‚Äôre problem isn‚Äôt addressed in their help me section. I am uninstalling the app again but I don‚Äôt see myself giving it a third chance after this

review:

 I was recommended this app and was told it wasn‚Äôt a scam, however upon further investigation this was proven invalid and completely ridiculous. title: SCAM SCAM SCAM SCAM SCAM SCAM

review:
If I could give this app a zero star, I would. 1) For you to get any real prize, say a $50 gift card, you‚Äôll have to walk OUTSIDE for 20 miles, that‚Äôs over 180,000 steps COUNTED. 2) This app doesn‚Äôt count all your steps. I just did an experiment of walking to the mall (it said 4310) and back and it said it only saw 51 steps. That‚Äôs $.04 sweatcoins. Mind you, I did not walk inside the mall, just from my doorstep to the the bus stop in front the mall and back (I live close by). The amount of steps on my Apple Watch was 7215 for both directions, while this app saying something different. Over 2800 steps off. 3) It drains your battery life significantly while open in the background. 4) it using your location constantly with no real reward for it. And I don‚Äôt see why it‚Äôs using the GPS if it cannot calculate the amount of steps it would take from point A to point B CORRECTLY. Makes no sense. 5) You‚Äôll have to pay money for these so call ‚Äúprizes‚Äù at a 3% discount rate (when you do the calculations). This is nothing but a scheme for you to sell your location and activity for nothing really. While forcing you to spend money on things you really don‚Äôt NEED. It‚Äôs a profitable business for the developers while us users lose. 

In conclusion, is this what you worth users? Sell yourself to someone who‚Äôs paying well for you, cause at the end of the day, that‚Äôs all this about, cyber prostitution. Just keeping it real. *App deleted*
title: Beware of this app

review:
I‚Äôm a college student who also works, so my walking is mainly to and from classes. In the past 8 months, I‚Äôve made roughly 500 sweatcoins( $25 USD) just from walking and doing their daily add rewards. All you‚Äôve got to do(this May be why I‚Äôve seen other reviews mentioning that steps aren‚Äôt counted correctly) is leave the app on. If you want to make an extra 15 sweatcoins a week, watch the daily add ever day. Each add is 30 seconds or less, so I usually watch them while walking to class. I haven‚Äôt even been doing the daily adds for long, so let‚Äôs assume that I‚Äôve only made 400 sweatcoins from walking, that‚Äôs still $20 for something I‚Äôm doing anyways. They also have some great deals in the app like joining twine for 100 sweatcoins and having them add $15 to your twine account ($15 equals 300 sweatcoins so it‚Äôs a better return value). 
All in all, the app isn‚Äôt always going to be extremely accurate on step counting, especially since they avoid counting steps inside building, but it‚Äôs money you‚Äôll get for essentially doing nothing so can we really complainü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è love the app. Will keep using it and will keep referring it to friends.

review:
This app is a SCAM!!! You think you‚Äôre earning free money just by walking around outside, but here‚Äôs the catch; the items you can purchase with your Sweatcoins still demand some of your own money for shipping, membership, etc. and you end up getting sucked into something you thought was a good deal, but I‚Äôve checked multiple times and they probably save you only $2 at most.
I‚Äôve read soooo many reviews saying that Sweatcoin ripped them off after they had already spent their unfairly earned coins for ‚Äúprizes‚Äù and when they tried to fix the problem with Customer Service, they never picked up, never returned phone calls, kept getting transferred to person after person, you name it. (I don‚Äôt say unfairly earned lightly, you could participate in 5 marathons in a day and they would only give you about $2 worth of coins) Thankfully, I didn‚Äôt experience this first hand because I was saving my coins for the ultimate price; $1,000. And I‚Äôm so glad I deleted the app before I invested too much time into it, because I would have been furious!!
ALSO, they track your location 24/7 to continuously count the steps you take every hour of every day, but honestly that is just straight up sketchy....Not worth it. ANDDDD they force you to keep the app running so it can be on in the background, lurking, tracking, and watching your every move. How creepy is that???
title: DON‚ÄôT waste your time with this app!!!

review: I do agree that the conversion rate is sometimes wonky, but I don't know where there are so many negative reviews. Everyone is saying how the app is "fake" "scam" and the prizes are "unattainable"  because it takes it you years to achieve it... But let me ask you something.. How much do you expect to get paid for walking? You should be happy youre getting paid at all. Do you expect them to give you 20$ a day just to walk?? Dont be ungrateful, if it takes you a little extra time to get the prize so what? whether you get it in 5 years or 10 years youre still getting the $1000, just for walking! Regardless if you use this app or not, youre still gunna be walking right?? Might as well keep this app on in the background and get paid. Sure its a small amount (its like 10cents a day) but still, youre 10cents richer, and in x amount of years itll cumulate to $1000. People nowadays are ridiculous, and so ungrateful. They expect to get everything in a blink of an eye, this app is amazing and a genius! It keeps me motivated to reach my goal. And sometimes I wouldnt mind taking the longer way when walking. I am so glad I found this app!
title: How much do you expect to get for WALKING?

A lot of apps that claim to do the same thing try to make you work way too hard to see any real profit, but this app was paying out from the get go. I took a long walk late at night (as I usually do since my PTSD & Depression keeps me wake from time to time) and before I knew it I earned 17 ‚ÄúSweatCoins‚Äù. It didn‚Äôt take long at all since I only walk around my neighborhood, down to the corner gas station and back home. I was out for an hour but only about 30 mins of that was spent walking. This app though is the epitome of you get what you put into it. So get out and grind and make you some ‚ÄúSweatCoins‚Äù I know I will lol.

review: This app is just a means of tracking you for free, and I will tell you why. The prizes take an extraordinarily long time to reach, even if you are walking the maximum amount each day. There is a $1000 PayPal prize which the app says is available after 18 MONTHS, but even if you are on the highest subscription, it would take you about 3 YEARS to earn this reward unless you referred the app to a ton of friends for 5 sweatcoins each. 3 years of data on how much you walk, how much all of your friends walk, and where. In the meantime you are left with some truly mediocre rewards (granted, I‚Äôve been on it for a day), forcing you to keep walking to try to earn an iPhone, gift card, or television . If you walk inside, the steps aren‚Äôt counted, but the app will still be tracking you without giving you sweatcoins. If you aren‚Äôt earning anything for being tracked then you should close the app to save your data/battery, right? Sweatcoin doesn‚Äôt think so. It will ping you with a notification saying ‚ÄúYou killed me! üò≥ Do not force quit me if you want to generate sweatcoins. Tap here or walk 1000 m to restart me.‚Äù This guilts people into constantly have the app running in the background all the time, which allows the company to gather GPS data and analyze your daily whereabouts without rewarding you. DO NOT download this app. Sell your GPS data to a company instead.

title: Iffy

review:
First off. You get paid to walk in credits that you can use on the app to get discounts or free shipping or donating money to causes. You never get real money. 

I downloaded the app for a bit of extra coin and the chance to donate to causes that deeply need the attention. So far I‚Äôve had this app for almost a year, I walk every day and I‚Äôve only made 300 credits, have the app open almost every day and haven‚Äôt spent any until today. Some of the offers to get ‚Äú50% off at **insert random store name**‚Äù require 14,000 credits. A lot of these offers expire so the only way to be eligible for the things they advertise outside of the app is to pay real money to boost the amount of credits you can get walking... the only GOOD thing I will say is that I think that donating for causes is amazing but I wish they would have that more causes available than some dumb shopping discount. 

They rarely have time for these causes it seems because I noticed causes are only on there for a day or 2 before ‚Äúexpiring‚Äù but they will keep a discount for a pair of headphones for weeks? It just completely defeats the purpose of advertising ‚ÄúGetting paid to walk‚Äù. Save the space on your phone and don‚Äôt get this app. I‚Äôm throwing all my money into the recent causes and never thinking about this app again.

review:
UPDATE-
I changed my review to one star because i have not received my order, made months ago, and after i reached out to CS, I‚Äôve heard nothing. It‚Äôs only $20 but I‚Äôve learned my lesson. 

My daughter put me onto this app because I am a serious runner and walker. Every day I don‚Äôt use this app and I‚Äôm up to near $500 in a short time. My issue with this app has nothing to do with my earnings but with the items that I should be able to purchase with my earnings. They sell you with the idea of earning these dollars or coins to purchase things but you never are really purchasing something. Everything is a percentage off. I‚Äôm buying coupons. And the fact that I‚Äôm not able to purchase only blows Mia more when I see that the things that I do want are always sold out. What I would like to have is never available. Ever. If you have a lot of people purchasing, you should have more available. Especially if you‚Äôre always selling out. If not, then it‚Äôs set up and a scam to me. Lastly if I‚Äôm only able to get so much off, maybe if it‚Äôs worth it I‚Äôll do it. But shipping is way too high. And I‚Äôve already purchased one item and it hasn‚Äôt even shown up yet. developerResponse: {'id': 11024096, 'body': 'Sorry to hear this. We have a small team, and try and get through all support tickets in a timely manner. Please email reviews@sweatco.in and we‚Äôll follow up this one for you ASAP. Team Sweatcoin', 'modified': '2019-10-02T16:18:07Z'}
review: I understand that this a small team (this fact was mentioned in the help section of the app). But I've contacted the developer three times now about a very serious issue and to date, no one has responded back. Not even an auto-generated email saying 'hey, your feedback has been received, your ticket is in a que'. I'm literally logged into SOMEONE ELSE'S ACCOUNT. The only way this could have happened is that my phone number (which I haven't had for very long) was attached to someone else's account before. Since we don't create login credentials during setup, there's no way for me to sign out of this individual's account and for me to sign into my own. This is a MAJOR security issue. Absolutely nothing in the forums or the help section is going to help me resolve this issue; I need to talk to an actual person. If you have time to make an app and update it (shows last update 4 days ago), you've got to make time for your customers too. Use a CRM platform with a ticketing system, there's plenty to choose from. And one more thing... this is a big one and I probably won't use this app until they change this... allow users to create login credentials during setup so something like what I'm experiencing doesn't happen to someone else. People's phone numbers change sometimes.

review: My sister and I both have this app and for the same exact time we walked right next to each other at Carowinds. My total amount of steps says 9,892 but only 830 we‚Äôre counted as outdoor steps, therefore giving me just 0.78 sweat coins. My sister‚Äôs, however, total amount was 11,065 of steps, and 9,227 were counted as outdoor steps therefore earning 8.76 sweat coins. Where is the logic in that? We have been outside the entire day and walked the same amount but i did not get even 1 sweatcoin from today. You guys need to fix the bugs. I think that people should still get coins and steps counted even if it IS indoors because at least they are actually walking? Why does it matter if it is inside or out? review:
I went to purchase these air pods and it continually told me it was out of stock, after constantly reloading the app, still not able to purchase while it still said the air pods 
 available. If there truly is nothing to be done, I‚Äôm just going to delete my account at this point and tell everyone what a waste this app really is. The reason I do this app is because I am low income and thought this would be a great way to have some small wins in the world where I‚Äôm stuck walking because of an accident. title: Wish I actually could get something

review:
I love the idea of an incentive based walking app, that‚Äôs great to promote a healthier society, but I‚Äôve been looking at the rewards, and you really aren‚Äôt getting anything with the ‚Äúsweatcoins‚Äù generated. Notice almost all of the daily rewards offered are free trials of an app or a membership of something, or a small discount of a product on a company. At this level, your sweatcoins are virtually valueless, considering most companies have these offers for new users as it is. If you look at the eye candy ‚Äúmarathon‚Äù rewards, you‚Äôll see some actual things worthy of earning (iPhone X, 1,000 dollars in cash), but after some math, assuming you have the best subscription possible, which offers 600 sweatcoins a month at a charge of 30 sweatcoins a month, the quickest you could redeem that reward while getting your daily bonus every 3 days consistently would take nearly 3 years. That‚Äôs a bit ridiculous. 

If you like walking and feeling a minor pat on the back for it with useless currency, this is the app for you. But I will credit the app for looking clean and not an eye sore, and having a cool color scheme.

review: I have been slowly saving my sweat coins with the intention of using them for a cash payout. Originally 1,000 sweat coins could be used in exchange for 1,000 cash via PayPal. So I patiently have been letting Sweatcoin use my location. When I reach 700 SC the advertisement for 1,000 cash via PayPal disappeared from the marketplace. Annoyed I kept using the app anyway incase something else better came along but I began to notice that the prices of goods started getting higher and higher. Today I checked in on the app. and the 1,000 cash via PayPal was back! But this time I needed 19,999 SC to redeem it. It‚Äôs taken me over a year just to get to my roughly 750 coins. Do not let this app fool you. First off there‚Äôs nothing good in the marketplace that you already can‚Äôt find a deal for online. Second when you get close to something worth your SC they bump the price up on you to a cost that is almost unattainable. Clearly this app is selling its data and location information from its users and does not plan to reward anyone except themselves. I also want to add that I am an extremely active person often hiking over 5 miles a day on the weekends and walking or running 2-3 miles on the weekday. If it took me over a year to get as far as I did how long will it take the everyday person?

It‚Äôs not like my friend is using that 3,000 so why can‚Äôt I just except it & use it for a 20,000 prize? It makes NO SENSE! Why have a transfer button if there‚Äôs a lot of prizes you can‚Äôt use the transferred sweat coins on.
title: Needs Work!!!!

review: Yes. you really do need to turn the battery saver off when you go outside. As a dog walker I am getting plenty of outdoor steps in. They are working on recording inside steps too, so if that appeals to you it‚Äôs worth downloading now to get in on the ground floor. I‚Äôm racking up an extra Sweatcoin every day just for viewing an offer or ad. In less than a week I had enough to get extra audiobooks which I like. I think that as the company grows they will be able to offer better rewards with more variety. Note to developers: seriously consider hiring a master negotiator to help you with this. You should be getting more stuff from your advertisers. More short term rewards- things a person could reasonably earn in about 6 weeks- will keep users coming back. Some of those offers that are just discounts aren‚Äôt attractive to a user like me. Overall I think the app is doing exactly what it promises now, and I believe the company that makes it is on the right track to make it better. Yes, this app is Recommended by me.
title: Works. Hopeful about it‚Äôs future.

review:
Membership pricing is upside down. The price per unit should go down with the larger size product you buy, giving shoppers an incentive to upgrade/switch past their current choice. You get 5 sweat coins a day (150/mo) for free. The shaker level gets you an additional 150/mo for a cost of .031 sweatcoins per sweatcoin enabled to earn. The quaker level only gets you an additional 300 sweatcoins per month potential, but costs 20 sweatcoins a month, or .066 sweatcoins per sweatcoins enabled to earn. Breaker level gets you 450/mo on top of the 150 free sweatcoins, but costs 30 sweatcoins - for again .066 sweatcoins per sweatcoins enabled to earn. The shaker level is actually the best priced option, if you stick in it for the long haul to earn sweatcoins, but it would take almost 5 years to earn enough to get the large prizes (10 sweatcoins a day + 1 free claim). So either the pricing strategy is upside down, or you are purposing pricing the products backward to limit the possible sweatcoins earned to prevent buyers from ever being able to claim the top prizes.

5 years seems like a big investment just to earn a $1000 PayPal gift card. I could use the time spent walking outside to instead get a part time job, with family, or anywhere in general that isn‚Äôt trying to rip me off.
title: Prizes out of reach, Pricing upside down

review: Don‚Äôt get me wrong, any app that you can get stuff for free just by walking is great! Sweatcoin is great! But.. everything is always out of stock. Now The app converts steps into ‚ÄúSweat coins‚Äù. These are then used as a currency and you can use the to get free stuff (like a $20 gift card) that you use the sweat coins to purchase. Some items you use your coins and just pay shipping. Some you get discounts on products. Some are completely free. There is a bidding section and if you don‚Äôt like anything at all, there is a donate option. There is also challenges where you walk so many steps (usually 250,000 steps in one month, 8k steps a day) you get entered in the a sweepstake. There are community challenges and those we all walk and Sweatcoin themselves donates(this month is 5 billion steps total and sweatcoin will donate to the elephant protection initiative) all that being said I recommend this app to EVERYONE! At the very least it can help you focus on getting more steps in your day! If the store wasnt sold out so fast on the good stuff I‚Äôd give the app 6/5 stars lol
title: Almost perfect!

review: This app isn‚Äôt accidentally considering some of your real steps as faked steps and it does use the health app. It takes the steps from health app and uses and algorithm aka a long math equation that says that you are losing steps. It doesn‚Äôt verify real steps cause how can you. It‚Äôs an app. Apps don‚Äôt know the difference. It‚Äôs all bs to keep you using it and inviting people cause that‚Äôs the only real way to build up sweatcoins. The app is scamming everyone that uses it and says things like ‚Äúturn of battery saver mode to lose less steps‚Äù cmon now. It‚Äôs literally telling you to let the app use more of your phones processing space or else you will lose sweatcoin steps. All the things it says it uses like gps and blah blah blah is also bs cause what would a gps do? Yeah it shows you moving but you could easily put your phone on an rc car and have the controller rubber banded going over books over and over to simulate a step and it should count. But guess what. It doesn‚Äôt, because the app is a scam into getting millions of people to download it and have businesses believe their product is going to end up on their store which it might but still wouldn‚Äôt be worth it in the end. Not only is this app a waste of time but it‚Äôs lying to you every second of your day.
title: Let‚Äôs be honest with eachother...

review:
I‚Äôve had this app since August 10th, and it is now December 2nd. Almost 4 months doing what I normally do, sometimes walking further due to the incentive, and I have almost 900 sweatcoins. Whether this app is accurate or not, it‚Äôs influencing me to be more active in order to achieve the end goal. I‚Äôm a huge advocate of this app, and the benefits of having multiple options of ‚Äúfree‚Äù trials for apps and programs are a nice added bonus. Seems like a nice way for the companies to advertise, and a nice incentive for people to be more active. According to my current goal of obtaining 20,000 sweatcoins in order to achieve the $1,000 or the newer iPhone, I should be able to get it in about 7 years. Seams like a long time from now but money is money and I just have to stay active to get it. Hopefully they update so I can advance to ‚Äútrouble maker‚Äù and get more sweatcoins, or lower the cash value to 250$ for 5,000 sweatcoins so that it‚Äôs more obtainable.

All in all, I think this app is a great idea! Thank you sweatcoins team.

- R.A
title: Follow your daily routine & get ‚Äúmoney‚Äù

review: They have some great looking rewards on here like a curved TV and 1,000$ cash back, as well as an iPhone X, but they each are 20,000 sweatcoins to purchase. And I did the math on that and even for you to be able to receive that on the highest paid subscription possible Walking enough to get 20$ a day AND daily bonuses everyday, it still would take you nearly THREE YEARS to get to that threshold. And for those of us who don‚Äôt want to pay for an app that is supposed to reward you with money, the whole reason I signed up was to earn money not spend it. They have little rewards like 10$ off your electric bill for 10 coins on the app which is much more fair. 1 coin to 1 real dollar is a good deal and still needs quite a lot of earnings to get the top reward. So my suggestion to the developers is make the top rewards a little more achievable, you can get those TVs and iPhone X for 1000$ or less, but charging 20x that amount in the app. Maybe 5000 coins in the app or even fewer closer to true value would get a lot more incentive for people to use the app because even though it‚Äôd still take a year or so for practically everyone it is a much more achievable and worth it goal at least in my eyes.
title: Unrealistic rewards

review: I usually don‚Äôt write reviews for apps but I‚Äôm starting to feel as though this app is unfair. I see a lot of reviewers applauding this app for attempting to motivate people to get outside and walk and that is great , however I‚Äôm a mail carrier so it‚Äôs my job to walk. I‚Äôve had sweatcoin since January (2018) and have had 1.4M steps converted. But I only have a little over 1,200 sweatcoins. That‚Äôs insane to me, 1.4M steps only gets me 1,200 sweatcoins. Plus I‚Äôm on the breaker subscription (cost 30 sweatcoins) since the app informed me I was losing steps with the other subscription I had. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend this app to people who just walk casually and are expecting to get rewarded for it. If you‚Äôre like me and will walk a lot regardless it might be worth it because you‚Äôre not losing anything. Even if it takes forever to accumulate enough sweatcoins for you to get something useful. The conversion shouldn‚Äôt be so stingy however. But I‚Äôll keep using it for now simply because like I said I‚Äôm not losing anything. As of right now they‚Äôre are some decent $50 gift cards that will cost you 3,650 sweatcoins , the biggest offers cost 20,000 sweatcoins so good luck with that. The other offers aren‚Äôt worth mentioning .
title: Conversion rate is frustrating

developerResponse: {'id': 13063388, 'body': 'Since our latest update, we‚Äôre aware of some issues for some users with step conversion. Please make sure that you have updated to the newest version of Sweatcoin first, and that you‚Äôve allowed us permission to access your Health Kit/Apple Health for the new step counting algorithm to work! Note that the new step counter isn‚Äôt available to those using an iPhone 6 or older model.', 'modified': '2020-01-22T14:38:38Z'}
review:
Ever since the new update that ‚Äòdoesn‚Äôt need gps‚Äô the app counts steps but still only gives you sweat coins for your outdoor steps. But since it doesn‚Äôt rely on gps it doesn‚Äôt know how many were actually outdoor steps so you‚Äôre only getting a fraction of what you walked. 
Case in point- while at a theme park one evening I walked over 8,000 steps, ALL outdoor, but instead of crediting all my steps (as it should since it‚Äôs not supposed to matter anymore if they are outdoor or in doors) it only credited 253 steps which it said were outdoor steps. Wha?? Why is it still trying to determine which steps were outdoor and only credit those if it doesn‚Äôt matter anymore if you walk inside or outside??
I wish I could go back to the previous version off the app. Or at least give me the option of relying on gps or not. 
Another small grievance I have, this is not limited to sweat coin but is the case with a lot of point gathering apps, that the options for spending them are limited to mostly coupons for subscription services. In other words, an invitation to spend actual money on a regular basis, instead of a way to save you money. It will never be an actual crypto-currency until it spends like currency.
title: New update doesn‚Äôt still doesn‚Äôt credit all steps

review: I went through the reviews after I got the app and I noticed some people that the rewards where fake but really should it matter if the rewards are good or not the app encourages you to walk more by getting rewards to do it like I was at a friends house and she lives on top of a hill it‚Äôs a half mile down and up to get to the mailbox and decided to walk down instead of using the car and I brought my phone with me to count my steps usually I would NEVER do this but the app encourages me to do so. I have asthma so with the air thinning out the higher I got on the hill and the exhaust of already walking down the hill was hard for me to do but I did it and it may have only gotten me $2 for it but it‚Äôs more about how you feel after you‚Äôve done it. Also I like the fact you can donate to things like planting trees and prevented child marriages. I enjoy this app very much and it has helped me be more active I would recommend to all my friends!!!! Thank you sweatcoin for encouraging me to be more active ü§ó.
title: Wonderful app

review: Say what you will about step conversion (like when I log 12k steps and only 3k convert), but I feel Sweatcoin is one heck of a motivator for me. My only issue is that it logged all of my steps for February 2021 as January 2021, now reflecting my February insights as 0, and as of today (March 3), I show 0 for March even though I‚Äôve ‚Äúboosted‚Äù on all three days and have hit nearly 10k steps each day (with at least 4-5k in pure workout run/jog)... AND I‚ÄôM A PAYING/SUBSCRIBED USER. With that being said - overall it‚Äôs very buggy, but if you‚Äôre not a super perfectionist, it‚Äôs a good little motivation tool. FYI: their customer service is bleh; I emailed them back in mid February and haven‚Äôt heard back. Not sure if they‚Äôre understaffed or overwhelmed, but based on the forums (...their own forums) I read before I emailed them, I didn‚Äôt expect any sort of timely response as it seems they don‚Äôt have the best reputation for replying to folks or being able to fix the most common issues... everything I‚Äôm having issues with has been mentioned multiple times before. Will I still use it? Yes. Will I still pay $0.99/mo for Turbo? Yes. Am I an idiot? Likely.
title: Love/Hate Relationship

review:
There is no problem technical problems!! I really love your guys‚Äô app but I don‚Äôt seem to spend my money on much and in light of the black live matter movement I was wondering if there was any way to use our sweat coins to support charity towards the NAACP or any official site that support these causes?
I had to ask because it seems like a very reasonable thing to add to your offers and you might find more people downloading your app to support these causes.
I see a lot of people don‚Äôt have actual money to support these charity‚Äôs, gofundme‚Äôs, etc but want to help and this could be an incredible way to boost your app, help a great cause and help others find a way to support important movements with movement! I don‚Äôt know another to contact you guys about those so I hope you will read this soon!
Really great job with coming up with this app but I think this could really enhance things and I would find myself using it even more and encouraging everyone around me to do the same.
title: Great app!! A suggestion tho

review: So the concept of this app is really great. You walk, you get coins, you get stuff. It even hooks up to your device that monitors your steps, I have an Apple Watch linked to it, so it uses that information. Very simple right? Except no, it‚Äôs not. Tell me how I will check my watch and it‚Äôll say that I walked 18,000 steps (I work at an outdoor exotic animal sanctuary so I KNOW almost all of that is outside) and I‚Äôll be all excited to see how many coins I got, to go to my app to see that the number of steps that were ‚Äúdetected by my device‚Äù were only 10,000 of which only 4,000 were ‚Äúverified‚Äù. That‚Äôs not even 1/4 of the actual steps I took and I think that‚Äôs ridiculous. And the first time it happened I brushed it off and figured it was a fluke but this happens every day and it‚Äôs really upsetting me. I work 12 hours a day outside and I walk A LOT. It‚Äôs just really unfair and I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôll keep using the app. But I gave it the two stars because the pay out is immediate and they constantly have new stuff you can get with your coins, which I think is really cool. Also, even if it‚Äôs not in battery saver mode, it doesn‚Äôt eat up your battery all that badly.
title: Great concept, horrible execution

review: I‚Äôve had sweatcoin since 2019. I have a little over 1.1k coins. No they can‚Äôt be used to convert to real money. It‚Äôs only used to buy things they have in the market. For example, you can buy a coupon/code with the sweat coins to get a certain amount off on a product by the people they‚Äôve partnered with. It‚Äôs an okay app. I would say the best thing on there are the items you have to bid for but bids can go as high as 17k-25k sweat coins or more. It‚Äôs hard to get that amount unless you walk an insane amount. The main issue I‚Äôm having right now is in regards to the step conversion. As of lately, it seems I‚Äôm being cheated out of one sweatcoin. It‚Äôs 1 sweatcoin for every 1 thousand steps but when the day is over I notice that I‚Äôve been getting one less than what I‚Äôm supposed to be getting. For example, yesterday I had 5 thousand steps but only got 4 sweatcoins and on another day I had 10k steps but only got 9 sweatcoins. What‚Äôs up with that? I haven‚Äôt had this issue before until now. It seems to be occurring after the new update. I‚Äôm not sure though.
title: Step Conversion Issues

review: Sweat coin is a good app. I like that it reminds you of how many steps you actually take cause you really don‚Äôt think about it. BUT I honestly think there should be new upgrades for the year 2020. I strongly believe you guys should turn the sweat coins into cash receiving the money by either cash app, Pay pal or a bank account. Reason being you have those dedicated to this app and it gives so much motivation to push harder than the next goals of steps you have. Well there‚Äôs a few things you guys should update: the items you can SPEND on and there should be like a daily reward you receive. The extra sweat coins from the adds are helpful but, add something more fun like a few mini games or a spin the wheel. I‚Äôm pretty sure you guys make A LOT of money you just have to think bigger sometimes though. It wouldn‚Äôt hurt to add extra features and I really hope my review goes father than this. Other than that I‚Äôm loyal to sweat coins and I don‚Äôt plan on removing it no time soon because like I said before the motivation of this app is amazing!
title: ‚ÄºÔ∏è

review: I haven‚Äôt been using this app but for a month; however the hype was enough for me to download and give it a try. I‚Äôll admit, it motivates me to get outside more for my exercises (which is wonderful) but I question the validity of the amount of sweatcoins earned. The daily bonus was exciting until two days ago, when it stopped adding itself to my sweatcoin count, yet still shows it as earned/collected. It‚Äôs a bonus, I didn‚Äôt do much for it but watch a video so the disappointment is there yet petty. Nonetheless, I have spoken with others who use this app and we also agree it‚Äôs a hinderance to have to remember to keep the app open and on our person. I feel a little ridiculous walking to our outside bathroom at work with my phone in my hand (every step counts!). I wish this app would sync with my iWatch. I have the first version and don‚Äôt plan on buying a new one just so the two are compatible. Anyway, all in all I like the concept and it‚Äôs done it‚Äôs job in motivating me to get outside more. So with a few minor tweaks it would earn five stars in my book.
title: Motivational

review:
Why, oh why, must this app deliver so much excitement, so much buzz, about getting "paid" to get your steps in towards become a more fit individual? That alone definitely deserves a round of applause for the folks that actually give a darn to better themselves and to get off of the couch and do something physical. 
I understand the algorithms, and applaud the developers that applied this to their app; makes the poeple participating to earn Sweatcoins feel like the system is actually legit. 
But why not move this same algorithms to people indoors as well? People work, people usually give a lot of their time to making a paycheck INDOORS. Getting outdoors sometimes isn't feasible when work hours are skewed and the weather outside is undesirable. It seems almost unfair to the folks that slave away during their work hours (especially the ones on their feet) or only have access to the corporate gym that's indoors. 
I know that the buzz of this app, but has left lots of people discouraged enough to delete the app and the "game" that they were so excited to be a part of. 
One day soon, I may redownload this app, ONLY if the developers create a version that can account for indoor steps.
title: Frustrating

review: Sweatcoin allows me, as someone not normally self-motivated to exercise, to want to step up my walking game. While I‚Äôve read that other users take issue with the accuracy of the step count, I have not personally encountered this. I like that I can look back on my stat history. The feature I think could use revamping is the reward system. They sell out lightning fast. The rumor is that they are being bought out by bots. So despite having the app for almost a month, I have not been able to redeem anything. Another added layer of difficulty here is the notifications mainly tell me to spin for bonuses. While I love being reminded of that, it would be very helpful if I could be informed about the gift cards, subscriptions and products just as often. One solution I would suggest is making the majority of offers ongoing. This way users can redeem gift cards and such from a catalogue of options once their step count allows them to reach a certain dollar amount.
title: Great concept, one concern

review: I really love the idea behind this app. The first few weeks I used it I was monitoring every day, doing daily bonuses etc. I upgraded to the next tier of step counting and something happened. 59-80% of my daily steps were discarded.  Considering that whenever I am inside I immediately put my phone on the charger and leave it there until I go out again this shouldn‚Äôt be happening. I suspect it is due to how they determine if you are inside or outside. I live in a place with underground markets etc. one day I was walking around a park above ground for a few hours and should have had more than 8k steps. All of the steps I‚Äôd taken during that outing were discarded because under the park there‚Äôs an underground shopping mall.    Sometimes I walk around outside my condo and steps are discarded presumably because they can‚Äôt tell if I am inside the four towers on this property or outside.  For reasons like this this app has become a lower priority.  They should change the algorithm to allow steps in commercial areas regardless of whether they are inside or outside.
title: I Love The Concept, But Algorithms Need to Be Improved

review: The app‚Äôs cool and what not being able to get some currency to purchase products. However, it‚Äôs really not for everyone. It‚Äôs not a app where it‚Äôs a gratifying or immediate payout. You really have to buy their other packages to fit all the steps if you walk a lot. I usually walk 10k everyday but sometimes the app counts all my steps. Now I don‚Äôt have the app‚Äôs other options where you pay to count or steps for currency but there are days where the app would count really little of my steps. Some days I‚Äôd walk 6,500 steps and I‚Äôd get $.15 of the app‚Äôs currency and I would be walking outside. Like I said the idea of the app is cool and all but it‚Äôs not overall great. Also a lot people who get to promote this app are shady lol. If you refer and get people to join then you get actual money, but to walk? Not the money people would have in mind. So as stated I have the free basic subscription which is $5 a day and I had this month for about 3 months which I walk about 10k a day, I was only able to get $161 of the app‚Äôs currency. It‚Äôs hard to get more ‚Äúmoney‚Äù for legit or good products. This app is really whatever and alright. I think it‚Äôs okay and I‚Äôm not too crazy about this.
title: It‚Äôs okay

review:
I work at a Convention Center, and on average, I walk 15-20,000 steps on a normal day. 30-40,000 when it‚Äôs insanely busy and I‚Äôm working overtime. That being said - the tracker never converts that many steps; therefore, my step balance is low, and I can‚Äôt ever afford any of the Offers.
Yet - even if I could afford an Offer - after two years of using this app - there hasn‚Äôt been one single offer that interests me. It‚Äôs like a digital Chuck E. Cheez prize center full of junk you‚Äôll never need or use. And there was maybe 2-3 Organizations that I was comfortable donating my Step Money to. 
The auctions for the items that ARE somewhat desirable - usually start off great - and then it‚Äôs always one user (that I theorize is a paid SweatCoin employee) that comes and jacks up the auction by the THOUSANDS. For example, when an auction bid goes from 500 SC TO 18,000 SC in one bid. It happens - EVERY - SINGLE - TIME to just be a ‚Äúcoincidence.‚Äù 
The tracker that your phone comes with, is the only tracker you need. Any app that claims to ‚Äúpay‚Äù you for your steps is just lying to you. They‚Äôre stealing your behavior data. That‚Äôs all you need to know.
title: Total Waste of Time

review:
So, I hope I can encourage at least ONE person to join. There are NO adds witch is great because sometimes adds can freeze your phone. But I do have that really bugs me witch is why when I first join I thought whoever made this is smart and I was going on a walk and I took so many steps I think around 1K because we went to the park and I walked around for like 30 minutes but nvm that I ONLY GOT LIKE 30 2$ AND SOME CHANGE BUT that was with the 95c for using it and redeeming my daily reward which I understand but say the next day I go outside and I don‚Äôt get the daily reward because I forgot to collect it and it doesn‚Äôt give me the $.95 that I earned and I would get around One dollar I‚Äôm guessing so I think that we need to fix the issue but it is a good app for getting money and doing stuff I guess but if you decided to join and that‚Äôs great because I met my goal of one person to join from me.???!! .!??!.!!?...!!???????
 

-Yours truly
Rachel Lee Brown
title: This is the best money app ever

review: I see this app advertised all over instagram, if i look at a random post, 60% of the time, i'll get this ad. I have no problem with ads, but false advertising is just annoying. Every ad, it shows people holding a bunch of money with a corny caption saying something like "This app pays you for walking ü§ëü§©," every single time, it's someone holding money, which is misleading because on the app, i've never seen any option to receive payment after earning money. I recently redownloaded it, and still, no option. I understand that if you wanted, you could sell the items you receive, but that's not even worth the money. Not only that, but it takes so much effort to get an item that interests you, first finding something of interest ‚Äîmost of it is useless junk, and the rest is often sold out‚Äî but if you somehow find something that suits your interest, it would take forever to achieve the amount of money necessary. I understand it's not supposed to be easy, but it shouldn't feel like it's impossible to reach a goal. Regardless, it's a waste of time, but if you're walking all the time anyway, it doesn't hurt to have the app.
title: False advertising

We're working all the time to add new offers into our app. The issue we face is making other brands see the value of steps as currency -- so it can be a challenge to get everyone on board -- but we assure you we‚Äôre doing our best, and there's some exciting things on their way to you so keep an eye out!", 'modified': '2023-02-14T20:17:13Z'}
review: To get rewards you have to have the app for a long time. I downloaded last year in may and i only had about 1000 dollars in sweat coin. Mind you, I am still in high-school so i get about 10,000 steps a day and a little less on the weekends. I hadn‚Äôt opened the app jn a little why because there was no use, I couldn‚Äôt buy anything good. Thats another thing, there are prizes for 5,10,15 dollars but they are not full prizes. Its like 10 percent off of something, or free shipping so its kinda pointless. But anyway, I open the app and it says I can get a bonus up to 3,000 sweat coin if I watch a video and send a link to my friends, well the video doesn‚Äôt work and my screen is just black. I give up waiting and just turn off my phone. About 20 minutes later I open my phone up, straight to sweat coin where I had left it and the app crashed and took all of my credit earned. Then at the end of the day for my 10,000 steps I got 98 cents. Thats all I have now. Just don‚Äôt waste your time, because the only way you might get something is if you run a lot and you pay for the upgrade.
title: Just don‚Äôt get it

review:
I‚Äôve had it downloaded probably since October. It seemed great at the time but you never really get want you want. Most of the stuff their seems great but I would never find myself using besides the gift cards which you never get because they either get sold out or the raffles just never pick you, and it‚Äôs really hard to tell if you won or not, if you lose they still give you the link, which led me to think I won so I spent a hour or 2 trying to get it to work and then I realized it said I hadn‚Äôt won but most of the text was blocked/stopped writing, so it was really hard for me to realize. They also advertised you could get digital money like pay pal or something but it‚Äôs not real, at most gift cards, (still good though). So I haven‚Äôt had the best experience, along with sometimes the adds not giving you anything in return , though that was a month ago, still it waisted my time.

From a confused and disappointed customer‚Ä¶
title: Great Idea Poor Execution

review: The idea of earning something for fitness is a really great idea. Unfortunately, the app is a waste of your time, battery and storage on your phone. The app offers currency known as ‚ÄúSweatcoins‚Äù that you can exchange for items and/or cash. This is a wonderful idea, but any reward that you might want is around 20,000 sweatcoins and you are only able to obtain 5 per day without paying for the ability to earn more. This means it will take you 4,000 days to earn anything significant. Not to mention that the algorithm that the app uses doesn‚Äôt accept a significant amount of your steps. For example, I had 13,000 steps one day, 90% of which were outside and the app only accepted 100, which is about 9 sweatcoin cents. This means it would take me roughly 550 years to get anything of actual value from this app. There are other ways to earn coins aside from steps that the app barely uses, either watch a video per day or refer other people to use this app. It is 5 coins for each referral and either 1, 2, or 4 for the video, depending on how many days you have watched consecutively and there is only one video per day. All in all, this is a good idea, but poorly executed.
title: Cool idea, waste of time and space

review:
I love idea of the app but...
First off those prizes are pretty much impossible to reach yes I know your supposed to work towards them but it‚Äôs unlikely you won‚Äôt get the prize unless you work towards them for 5-8 years. The step counting algorithm makes it impossible to earn the marathon prizes in 1-3 years
This brings up a second problem. I have really bad allergies and can‚Äôt walk outside constantly without feeling like I have the plague but, sweatcoin only counts outdoor steps. I do walk a lot, I walk around my house, at school, and at work. My fit bit says I walk around 20-30k steps a day. I‚Äôm not one to easily just sit and do work. But every once in a blue moon I do decide to go out and walk after slathering on countless and allergy medications and taking several epipens so I can earn some coins and get some exercise in. I will walk 10k steps and only get about .5 coins which is ridiculous.
There should be some kind way to calculate indoor steps so I can work towards the bigger prizes. Love the idea of the app to get more people moving but, the app needs serious improvements before you can truly win something with the app.

1) Like previous reviews have mentioned. I‚Äôll walk an average of 18k steps a day 95% of these being outside. Sweat coin will only acknowledge 11k out of them. Since I have a limit of 15 coins a day I still need 5k sweat approved steps for me meet that goal. But honestly with light decreasing daily it‚Äôs getting harder to acquire more steps due to sweat coins poor algorithm calibrations. 
2) during 20 min 2x boost I have been severely swindled. During the 20 min I try to walk about 1.5- 2 miles which is over 2k steps, which would yield a boat of 4 coins total. There have been times that I only attain 0.04 coins or .5 coins or 1 coin. These simply don‚Äôt make sense as I am walking continually for 20 min. In addition the 2x pedometer screen is not in sync with the pedometer that shows how many steps there are to analyze (with the button that says analyze now). Also I‚Äôve noticed randomly the 2x pedometer screen will read an absurd number such as -17,450 steps. Don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs up with that. 
I like this app because I enjoy walking and do so for my daily work commute. But I want this to properly reflect my steps. My phone is new iPhone SE and up to date. I hope developers can address these issues. Thank you.
title: Cheats out of points.

review: I got this app because the description describes and quotes users describing things like ‚Äúfree money,‚Äù ‚Äúextra cash,‚Äù and ‚Äúgetting paid to walk.‚Äù I have had this app for half a year now, and I have yet to be able to take advantage of my nearly 500 sweat coins. It is not ‚Äúfree money,‚Äù it‚Äôs just discounts. There is not a single reward option that does not cost actual money except for their most prestigious offers (which typically cost 20,000 sweat coins), which could take years to afford. Just for perspective, I am a college student, so I am constantly walking across campus, and I also work two internships that require me to walk around downtown quite a lot. I walk much more than the average person, and it would take me over 5 years to get anything actually ‚Äúfree.‚Äù If you are poor like me, you know there is a HUGE difference between free money and a discount. I do not have money to spend, and giving me discounts doesn‚Äôt change that. If you do not want to spend your own money in order to take advantage of their rewards, don‚Äôt bother downloading this app. I work for multiple attorneys and am honestly considering taking this to court for false advertisement. What a complete waste.
title: Misleading

review:
I don‚Äôt normally write reviews. Figured this one was worth writing because I actually do like this app. There limited things to purchase and any things worth purchasing seem extremely out of reach. However, it‚Äôs all free so hoping they increase their options one day.

My biggest disappointment in this app is the step converter. I walk all day during work and I easily break 5k steps per day. With the free version, I maxed this out 3 days in a row and al my steps converted just fine. Since I surpass this amount on a daily basis, I upgraded my account to get 10k stars per day. As soon as I upgraded, I got zero steps for pretty much every day after (about 2-3 weeks worth). I got all the updates, I opened the app frequently (and have always tracking turned on in settings) and still nothing. I then canceled my upgrade yesterday and boom... my steps began converting again. Not sure what‚Äôs going on !74 quite disappointed. I feel like I lost out on 140k steps fo no reason. 

Anyways. It‚Äôs all free so whatever, but for the broken converter I give it 3 stars.
title: Paid for more steps and got less

review: Ok first of all I really don‚Äôt think an app that pays you for just taking a walk outside needs any introduction. This is possibly one of the best apps I have ever decided to download. Instantly as you open the app it takes you through a tutorial so you know how everything works. After that they give you many special offers. Learn from my mistakes in the first week always try to get those special first week only offers done. They are very beneficial. After that they just set you free with all of there deals and you are instantly saving money. Sense this is a crypto currency and the worlds technology is advancing it may be a good idea to get a head start on this app it may be a powerful governmental tax payment tool in the future. Even if you don‚Äôt extra size if you just walk outside a little like on your way to work you are saving money. If you haven‚Äôt got my point yet, THIS APP GIVES YOU FREE MONEY!!!
title: Strong Ideas Often Have Strong Outcomes.

review:
I downloaded this app a few years ago and never really used it. The rewards were out of my point range and it was a slow process earning points so I never bothered. Started walking more about a year and a half ago so started accruing lots of points daily. Problem is I check the rewards almost daily and have never seen any gift cards that aren‚Äôt sold out. There are a few options to buy discounted jewelry or other items I‚Äôm not interested in purchasing or links to memberships and subscriptions I could get directly from the vendor and skip the middle man. 
There is no actually reward I will ever be able to attain so it is a waste of my time and use of my phone‚Äôs battery and storage. 
There are better apps that actually reward you for using the app. It‚Äôs ridiculous to spend over a year trying to spend the points you‚Äôve earned. Sweatcoin needs to figure out a way to make spending points fair for everyone but they haven‚Äôt so I‚Äôm deleting the app at the end of this month. I gave it a fair chance but would not recommend the app to anyone if they are hoping to actually be rewarded. ‚úåüèª
title: A huge waste of time!!!

developerResponse: {'id': 23128800, 'body': "Hey,\nThanks for your review!\nSorry you haven't found anything you like yet -- we are working hard to partner with other companies who value your steps as much as we do, but we hope you understand this can be tricky! However, we are adding new offers all the time, so keep an eye out!", 'modified': '2021-06-01T12:36:32Z'}
review: For the past four years while I've had this app installed, I've had a job as a walking field technician, spending every day walking the streets of Manhattan. Every day I would walk between 5 to 10 miles per day. After four years I have racked up enough points to get nothing more than what I'd likely get if I walked 0 miles. I've received nothing free, and the best I could attain with the points I've acquired are things like "3 months free of Apple Music", or other discounts that are likely available other places without walking every day. Although I always had faith that I'd eventually rack up enough sweatcoin points to get something cool, today I came to accept that this is all nonsense, that it's impossible to attain the amount of miles to get anything good, and that I'm finally going to delete this app because it's really just a marketing engine. There's no way anyone walks enough to get any of the "free stuff" flaunted in the marketplace of this app, take it from me, someone who walks at least a marathon per week. Shame on you, sweatcoin, for giving me false hope for the past four years.
title: Used This App For Four Years, And It's Not Worth It

review: The app is great for just picking up small items but I think you shouldn‚Äôt have to have it open all the one and if you close it you lose steps I don‚Äôt see why if it verifying from the health app which is never open, the app then has to be open, also the inaccurate step count I work during the night and I still walk around all day but I‚Äôm not getting the right amount per how much I put in, pulse closing the app by accident and I lost 1 sweat coin in total which is 1000 steps worth I don‚Äôt see how it‚Äôs a possibility when the health app saves and says I too the steps, an last but not least the step count max look I understand you need to make money on the app but I think the limit for free should be a little higher than 5 I feel like it should be 8 and everything bumped up accordingly only dedicated people who pay walk the amount you have to pay for so for the regulars just bump it up, besides this it‚Äôs a great app
title: Like the app but a few things are stopping it from being 100%

review:
This app is way cool than its ‚Äúcounterpart‚Äù life coin. For one, the prizes are more affordable, cooler and you can pay for membership levels with sweat coins. My only issue is the inability to link to either apple health or my Fitbit. Sweatcoin says this is because they use gps to cut down on cheating? To make sure your outside? Because wearable devices tend to have extra steps due to arm movement?.... and there‚Äôs a battery saving mode so that‚Äôs nice..... 
After reflecting  of these statements, 1. The option to link to apple health might deal with the step issue, it still drains my battery, the reason I got a Fitbit was because of all the steps I was loosing on apple health because I don‚Äôt take my phone with me everywhere( for sanity and mental health reasons) I don‚Äôt see why they can‚Äôt just subtract a percent of steps from wearable devices... and the BIG concern.... I‚Äôm not sure I want an app constantly knowing my location ... seems creepy. 
Either way, it‚Äôs still super cool and I‚Äôm looking forward to improvements.
title: Awesome but....

review:
The idea of this app is very interesting and I believe that it gives people a reason to be more active. I myself have been more active and have been doing my part in trying to earn those sweet coins. It feels very satisfying to see how many steps were taken in your daily routine and the fact that u get rewarded for it is great as well. However, the biggest issue that I have and hopefully they do fix this is that the algorithm for the conversion of steps is very frustrating to deal with. The reason for this is because the algorithm cuts the steps u took by an exponential factor. I understand perfectly why the algorithm was developed this way. But for those who are actually honest like myself are being affected by those who try to cheat the system. 

The main reason I wrote this is because today I did a total of over 12,000 steps and that amount was converted to an approximate 700 steps. This is very frustrating and I really do hope that the sweet coin team reads my review and hopefully try to fix the algorithm. Please.

title: APP CHEATS YOU!! READ READ ASAP!!!

review: The app is such a good idea but I don‚Äôt understand why it was released when the algorithm they use isn‚Äôt even computing all the steps you make, they do clearly say that only 60% of the steps you make are counted and they‚Äôre always improving it but it‚Äôs just asking for bad reviews when you take 1000 steps and roughly only 600 are counted. title: Great idea but pretty bad delivery

developerResponse: {'id': 16141231, 'body': "Thanks for your review!\nSorry about this, but having your phone on low power mode is most likely the issue here... we don't work too well on low power mode, and not all steps can get through :(", 'modified': '2020-06-22T10:33:02Z'}
review:
The step counting is very inconsistent, the last two days I have taken over 11,000 steps and didn‚Äôt receive any sweatcoins (normally you would receive 1 per 1,000 steps). This is constantly a problem, most of my steps, but not all, are done indoors while I‚Äôm at work but sweatcoin claims that they can count indoor steps now so that shouldn‚Äôt be an issue. In addition the prize selection is lacking, most of the prizes are either really cheap but you‚Äôre only buying a coupon code/discount or they are ridiculously expensive and could take years of using the app before someone could earn them. There needs to be more intermediate rewards. The only things this app has going for it are the fact that it‚Äôs free and that you can donate sweatcoins to charity.

Update: iPhones have terrible batteries so I keep my phone on low power mode, for months this wasn‚Äôt an issue but now suddenly it tells you it can‚Äôt count indoor step, which is bad enough, but it‚Äôs actually not counting any of my steps anymore. The prize situation has gotten somewhat better which is great but this new development is significantly worse than my previous complaints.
title: Could be a lot better

review: Every Sweatcoin is worth 1,000 steps. That is reasonable. What isn‚Äôt however is that you have to devote Two Years for any of the good products. This is a little odd. If I have enough I should just be able to buy the item. Other than that, you cannot just sit and shake your phone. The app uses gps to make sure you are moving. This I had to test out for my self and I generated 200 stems just shaking my phone and it only accepted 12. Great job. Kudos. Now an awesome feature would be a daily brain challenge so you can exercise mentally and physically. Make it worth a sweatcoin. There really aren‚Äôt very many products to choose from but they cycle out daily. I‚Äôm not sure if I like it or hate it. If you see a product you want, you have to think. If you don‚Äôt have enough coins, you have to risk not being able to get the thing you want. Easy fix. Bookmarks on the products. When you go back to see your bookmarked items they would be listed as a goal list.

review: In this app you earn ‚ÄúSweatcoin‚Äù for walking, not actual dollars. You can only spend them in the shop, which has no products of actual value. They have a small section of ‚Äúphysical products,‚Äù but often the Sweatcoin can only get you a discount on it, and things you can actually purchase in full with Sweatcoin sell out very early in the day. I have never managed to snag one, but people say you have to pay astronomical shipping, which makes the whole thing feel like a scam. Sweatcoin has essentially no value to purchase or reduce the cost of anything. Now they are launching their own crypto currency but 1) it is worth less than a cent per share so after more than a year of walking my shares are worth less than $20 and 2) I can‚Äôt actually cash out. This is basically just a little game where you can earn pretend tokens. If that motivates you to walk, great, but there are other apps that do that better and you shouldn‚Äôt expect actual dollars.
title: Worthless

Additionally, you can now walk to earn crypto in our Sweat Wallet app so we'd advise checking that out too if our Sweatcoin offerings aren't appealing to you :)", 'modified': '2023-07-06T18:06:09Z'}
review: I have been walking for a long time now. I have a good amount of sweatcoins saved up which I want to spend on something actually good. However, you cannot buy a single item just from your sweatcoins. Let me explain further: The app has a marketplace where you can spend your sweatcoins. Other apps which have similar concepts would have shops where you can buy a giftcard or a gamjng console or a toy or a makeup kit from your earned currency, but not Sweatcoin! Inside the marketplace, all you can ever buy are discounts for actual products. For example, pay 50 sweatcoins to earn a 34% discount on a shaver kit or pay 10 sweatcoins to earn $3 off your first purchase in a restaurant or some crap like that. YOU WILL NEVER BE ABLE TO BUY A PRODUCT! If they ever do have giftcards, they are only available through sweepstakes, which you never win. Even if you pay to become a premium member, you still have no options to buy a physical item or giftcard with your own money! I check the marketplace every 3 days and there has been nothing I have been able to buy with my thousand sweatcoins.
title: No Good Items In Marketplace.

review: I‚Äôve been on SweatCoin since 2018, I‚Äôve had a free subscription and I‚Äôm currently on a premium subscription, neither one gets you anything good in the marketplace unless you‚Äôre in this app 24 hours a day. I‚Äôve been lucky to get a $10 Starbucks gift card once in 4 years, that‚Äôs the best item I‚Äôve been able to purchase with my sweat coins because they may have 200 gift cards for 500,000 subscribers, how does that make sense? The discounts for the physical products sounds like a good idea but I‚Äôve used these discount codes for several items that were never delivered and the companies don‚Äôt respond to request for refunds. I‚Äôve lost money and SweatCoin won‚Äôt refund the money I‚Äôve paid for the missing product, they‚Äôll just refer you back to the company that ripped you off in the first place. This app is a good idea in theory but after 4 years of lackluster experiences, when my subscription is done I‚Äôm gonna delete this crap and move on with my free step counter on my phone and not lose any more money or time.
title: Use the free step counter on your phone.

review: I have been using this app for about two years now and was consistently getting around 20k+ steps a day which usually maxed out my 15SC/day subscription (which costs 20SC/month). It‚Äôs been an amazing app and was perfect for me since my job involves a lot of outdoor walking. Ever since the new indoor step counting update my points have NOT been auto converting like they have been so I‚Äôve been manually converting them each night before bed (if I forget to manually convert I now end up with 0SC for the day converted with around 20k steps logged) and have watched my SC dwindle down to almost nothing per day. I am writing this review now because after converting my steps for the day (19,725) the app says that only 278 of those were approved. Those 278 steps converted to 0.26SC... I have done what the ‚ÄúHelp‚Äù page has said and tried closing the app, deleting and reinstalling multiple times and have not seen any improvement. I would like to keep using this app but cannot see myself continue to manually convert my steps every night just to see less that 1SC.

review: I have only been using this app for 3 months or so but I am really getting to like it. title: Great but needs some improvements

review: This app is great for your health and keeps you entertained while watching your sweat-coins raise but the app says you can buy cool prizes and they will pay for you with your sweat-coins that they change to money... but when you try to get the prizes (and have enough sweat-coins) the prize you want is charging you and the app won‚Äôt pay for it. title: Good but also meh..

review:
Is anyone talking about how none of these deals are specific to sweat coin? You can get the same deals that are being advertised on the Sweatcoin app if you go to the product‚Äôs website that is being advertised. 
For example, if Sweatcoin posts an ad for BarkBox being 50% off  your first box with sweatcoins, the same deal is running if you just go straight to BarkBox‚Äôs website‚Äîmaking sweatcoins value at zero.
This process seems obvious but this app advertises itself to make it look like sweatcoins are some kind of actual currency.

The only thing that made it seem somewhat like a substitute currency was the ability to donate sweatcoins for fundraisers, which I don‚Äôt see anymore. I wish we could see data that directly proves some sort of finances are being donated to these fundraisers from the users of this app. Is it? Is this app doing anything besides just tracking my steps? This is literally the second review I‚Äôve written for anything in my life. So congratulations Sweatcoin for being so worthless that I felt the need to write about it to warn other people.
title: Sweatcoins do not substitute currency in any way

review:
This app is pretty cool. It counts your outdoor steps and has new rewards every few days. There are a few things I don‚Äôt like about it: 
-You have to keep it open in the background. The LifeCoin app doesn‚Äôt make you keep their app open all the time to count your steps. I wish Sweatcoin would do the same.
-if you accidentally close the app during the day or at night close it cuz you‚Äôre going to bed, you get ‚Äúscolded‚Äù by the app every single time you reopen the app. Ok bro you‚Äôve told me like 285 times already since I‚Äôve had the app. 
-Normal Rewards are typically subscriptions and products like face masks, thermal phone cases, etc. there are cash rewards but they‚Äôre ‚Äúmarathon‚Äù rewards.  But anyway, when you redeem a reward you have to use it within 48 hours. I understand there being a time limit but that‚Äôs ridiculous; I bought a reward for 50% off something and didn‚Äôt wanna buy it right away. Living social and Groupon doesn‚Äôt have such short time limits.
title: Almost Perfect

review: This app has a great idea behind it. And, you do actually earn money faster than other apps I‚Äôve found like this. BUT, it needs work! Lots of it. Why are all the offers so unrealistically expensive? It‚Äôs like they set you up to never actually be able to get any of them. Also, they‚Äôre all health related? What if I don‚Äôt want to use my sweat coins on something health related. There‚Äôs no options to actually ‚Äòcash out‚Äô unless it‚Äôs by inviting 80 million people? What sense does that make? You have partners who are paying for adds and to put themselves on there an offer, so clearly a cash payout would be a realistic option. Unless you‚Äôre just trying to cheat people. Then there‚Äôs also the fact that no inside steps count?! I‚Äôm sorry what? My work is very high paced and I‚Äôm on my feet ALL DAY LONG but, it‚Äôs inside so 95% of my steps (over 3000 daily) don‚Äôt even count?! In what world is that fair?! Again, I think there‚Äôs a good concept behind the app but overall it‚Äôs very unfair and impossible to actually gain anything from...
title: Needs a lot of work

review:
I live in the mountains of Western NC. I have always walked but in Feb 2019 I decided to pay more attention to the amount of walking I do.  In June I stumbled on your app while playing Wordscapes.  The first few times the info popped up I simply ignored it. Then one day I took a look and figured what can it hurt.  I am very happy that out here in the mountains you are able to pick up the GPS signal.  Typically, I walk close to 20,000 steps daily.  There have been a few times when the count picked up by the app has been off - but overall I think it does a pretty good job. 

I don‚Äôt really care about the ‚Äúrewards‚Äù or ‚Äúoffers‚Äù because it seems to be a way to sucker you into subscriptions that just cost you money in the end.  I did purchase the $$ from PayPal but was disappointed about the way the offer is presented. It sounds as if all you need do is have people sign up and use the app but then you are told you have to give up 30 SWCs to get the PayPal $6.  That seemed a bit lopsided to me. 

The chance to help out with various causes appeals to me but I have not figured out what needs to be done to participate in these.  If I‚Äôm going to lose SWCs I‚Äôd rather lose them for a good cause. 

For now I just keep racking up daily points It‚Äôs a daily boost to my spirit when I get the feedback that I have met my daily goal. I figure I‚Äôll go up another level once I have hit the current mark for 30 straight days.
