review: I downloaded this app a little over 5 months ago. It started off great, I would reach and sometimes exceed the amount of steps allowed for the day. And then I upgraded to pay 10SWC a month to maybe earn a few more coins while I work (I work in the kitchen so I‚Äôm moving around and working all day). For the past month or so I get cheated out of THOUSANDS of steps everyday and now I can‚Äôt even get close to the steps allowed for the day. I actually enjoyed walking because of the app and it‚Äôs offers for today, but I can‚Äôt really enjoy if I‚Äôm continuously get cheated. I worked an almost 13 hour shift today, how I only walk 12,000 steps and only earned 4.52. Also, it occasionally restarts the app(when I go to look on another app) as if you never opened it today so I get cheated out my coins because of that I believe. I‚Äôll keep it for another week to see if something will fix itself but if not I will not hesitate to delete this app. ü§∑üèæ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
title: Pretty decent app at first....

review:
Do you want to count steps at the gym? This is not built for you. Do you walk around in nature parks? This is not built for you. Do you walk relatively fast? This is not built for you. For reference, I‚Äôm 5‚Äô1 and I am by no means a fast walker‚Äîthis app only counts every 3rd step of mine. I can‚Äôt imagine how frustrating this might be for someone faster than me or someone with long strides (which might confuse the conversion ‚Äúalgorithm‚Äù). 
It also only transfers steps on wifi and loses some of the progress you made when you weren‚Äôt on wifi. Which totally defeats the purpose of walking outside. And since walking at the gym is too fast, you‚Äôre screwed either way.
Now I‚Äôm aware the company is gonna respond to this with some BS about how they‚Äôre going to fix it after my review but I‚Äôve had this app for awhile (half a year) and back then they said the same thing to other people. I‚Äôm going to keep it around to get what points I can but everyone else who gets this app needs to be aware of its many many limitations.
title: Keep Your Expectations LOW

review:
I kept wanting to download this because I walk a ton & thought hey, if I can get something out of it I might as well. 
It links up well with my watch so far & counts all the steps I take as far as I can tell. 
However, the ads I kept seeing for this app said that I‚Äôd get ‚Äúpaid to walk‚Äù. This is simply not the case. You can‚Äôt transfer sweat coins to any type of currency (I‚Äôve looked all over for that option), you can only redeem them for rewards. And the rewards are pretty limited. I‚Äôve looked through them several times & there just aren‚Äôt many. The big ones you would want to save up for would take a ridiculous amount of time to earn. You have to upgrade to get more than a few sweat coins a day & upgrading will cost you sweat coins. You‚Äôd have to live in a place like NYC where you walked most days to even come somewhat close to getting bigger rewards. 
Overall- It‚Äôs okay but not what I was expecting. Not sure if I will keep it unless I find some rewards that interest me.
title: meh - it doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúpay you‚Äù

review: I have been using sweatcoins for more than a year now. I loved it initially and when I got new iPhone it stopped recording the steps accurately, I contacted Apple as well as sweatcoins team, even changed my iPhone twice, it still did not work that well!! After a year I spent my sweatcoins to buy a watch and I did receive my watch, but that came defective, contacted the vendor from where I bought, they are saying that I need to go to a local shop to get new battery, which I did finally, but no local shops touch it becAuse I did not buy from them. I contacted sweatcoins team for a refund of the sweatcoins, because I received defective item, they are saying that it‚Äôs between myself and vendor, they can‚Äôt help. But in the end I feel cheated!! So if you are using sweatcoins and think that you will get something to get for free, so I would say that you may feel really cheated at the end, again it depends if your item is also defective, so my advise is to use as activity tracker or something to motivate yourself.

review:
I have a lot of fun with the app, and have developed some level of obsession. I only write reviews when I feel very very strongly about it, and being a professional content/app tester at a software company, I have had my own share of frustrations with the UI, and annoying bugs I‚Äôve seen with Sweatcoin over the years.

1. Please implement an ‚Äúabort‚Äù option for the 2X Boost, because sometimes it just gets stuck on ‚ÄúAnalyzing‚Äù forever. The problem is, when I start the boost at the beginning of my walk, it doesn‚Äôt update the rest of the steps due to this bug, and gives me 0 step. Very fristrating.

2. Please do a good job of reviewing your make partners‚Äô (sponsors) ads. Make sure they are able to submit their advertisements ONLY if they don‚Äôt try to do something shady, like making the ‚ÄúX‚Äù (close) button so crappy that I have to press an exact point within that ‚ÄúX‚Äù or else I‚Äôll get taken to the app store like 5 times before being able to actually close the app.

3. Please make sure that your ads don‚Äôt get stuck while loading. This happens at least 2-3 times a week and it‚Äôs very frustrating. After waiting for a while, I force close the app and restart and usually it will work fine, but sometimes it takes numerous tries.

Again, I enjoy the app but these points have made me delete the app a couple times. For better engagement please address these issues.

title: Much better

review:
This app is great for getting you moving. If you have a watch that is also connected to your health app, it also tracks that so you don't have to have your phone on you 24/7 to earn the coins. It's a neat feature. And the coins you earn can be given to charities to help fight for different things. Reproductive rights is one, safe drinking water is another. And I think I also saw a charity to help plant trees.

However, I wish there was a way to cash out the sweat coins you get once you reach a certain amount. I love the fact you can donate them to charities as you get the coins, but I'd love for a way to cash out to a PayPal account or something. There might be in the paid version but I've not been able to find one in the free version. Might be selfish of me to want that option, but if I'm working hard for them I'd like to see my efforts of hard work.

I downloaded the app originally because a friend recommended to me and said she got free food through an offer, but since I‚Äôve had it, the only offers that are redeemable are discount codes to companies or subscription services I have no interest in. For instance, there is a $100 delivery credit available from Postmates. However, this credit is given to all new customers and similar discount codes (of $100) are always given out by the company. So why would I use Sweatcoins for a discount when I can get that discount anyway?? It makes no sense. Another example is the free trial of Disney+ which is obviously just available to everyone on Disney+‚Äôs website..... Offers like these make Sweatcoin seem like a total scam. Additionally, sometimes the same, useless offers go away and come back a week later as ‚ÄúNew‚Äù. Hellooooo, they‚Äôre not new! 

Sweatcoin should not partner with companies that don‚Äôt offer exclusive, free products. I‚Äôm sick of discount codes for things that (1) I‚Äôm NOT interested in and that (2) I could get for free without Sweatcoins.

Seriously step it up!! Other reward programs I‚Äôm in (like T-Mobile Tuesday‚Äôs) often offer free food, drinks, water bottles, etc. Why can‚Äôt Sweatcoin do the same? FIND BETTER PARTNERS!

title: Meh

review: I‚Äôve been using this app since May 2017. In three years I‚Äôve taken millions of steps. I‚Äôm always in the top 10% of earners. In fact I‚Äôm being credited for almost all of my steps. However...... as I‚Äôve accrued more and more coins, the prices keep going up just as fast, so I‚Äôve not been able to purchase a single thing. In fact, it‚Äôs looking like this app is just  another SCAM! My friends that also have Sweatcoin, have offers on their phones Sweatcoin application that do not  show up on mine. In fact as soon as I reach the number to actually buy something, two things happen, either the purchase price sum in Sweatcoins increases (goes up)for the offer, or the offer simply disappears from the app. Just today it happened again for the upteenth time! I cannot recommend this app if one ever wishes to actually earn enough to spend on one of the very, very elusive Sweatcoin offers shown on the app. Take it from me, up to today a very loyal 3 1/2 year member who earns an average of 15-25 sweatcoins per day. Don‚Äôt bother with this Scam application.
title: Sweatcoins are becoming worthless!

review: This app allows you to earn money, by walking. More in depth, you earn sweatcoins(points), by how many steps you take throughout the day. These points can be used to buy items on the app. The app offers more than that, sometimes I stress the fact that I can not help the world, as much as I want to. I‚Äôm not rich, so I can‚Äôt buy a house for everyone, but this app allows you to earn points, so you can help people who need help. I feel like a much greater person, I‚Äôm giving back to the world, it may not be much, but I know I‚Äôm contributing more than I would‚Äôve without the app. I want to say ‚Äúthank you,‚Äù to the creators of this app, because they are helping the world through a free app, not many people do that. What the app has become is beautiful, it‚Äôs benefiting many people in the world, and benefiting many animals, so thank you.

review:
Especially in a pandemic like we are right now, this app should have the option to transfer the money/sweatcoins to PayPal for the extra cash that we need. I‚Äôve walked so much but I can‚Äôt use the ‚Äúmoney‚Äù I have earned because 1. I don‚Äôt find anything in the store on the app, interesting. 2. There‚Äôs no PayPal option. 

I think this app would get a lot of attention and love if PayPal was an option to transfer the ‚Äúmoney‚Äù we have greatly earned.

Reply to Developer:
There‚Äôs a few things that you could do for PayPal. If you think correctly, not a lot of those ‚Äú50 million‚Äù users earn a lot of money fast. 
It takes a lot of walking and exercising to get to a big lump some of sweatcoins. 
You could make it a goal for a lot of users to get to a certain amount of sweatcoins to be able to turn it into real money. 
Like, say 20,000 sweatcoins. A lot of people will wait for that amount AND it will encourage people to actually go out for a walk and stay active. 
I‚Äôm very active and I‚Äôve been on sweatcoins for a good two years I believe.
And also, you have to take into account that a lot of ‚Äúusers‚Äù aren‚Äôt users. They just created an account and never deactivated it. So whatever accounts aren‚Äôt accumulating any sweatcoins, your team should work on a solution to erase accounts that aren‚Äôt used. Then contact the user via e-mail to let them know.
title: Great App But Needs PayPal

review: Getting the coin is easy. Soending it on what really has value is another story. Mostly, its coupons and auctions, which, if youre not mostly invested in tracking, you just wont win the auction, which is par for the course on any app that uses digital currency to exchange for auction tokens. Youll soend more getting tokens than you will winning auctions unless you live on your phone and in this app. Same is true for gift cards. Unless you pay attention every waking moment, prepare to be disappointed to see ‚ÄúSold Out‚Äù all the time. Which is a shame, because it really feels like a penalty when in reality, its a supply-side issue, or at worst, a bad business model. Either way, Im saving up sweat coins and waiting to see if my experience improves. I have a job that keeps me busy and moving around a lot. Which is the upside to having this app. But if all I can do is donate and buy coupons and always miss out on the gift cards, well, that seems like a waste of effort.
title: Still deciding if worth premium cost

review: I‚Äôm just gonna put this out there: the ads you see for this app aren‚Äôt really legit. It shows people holding stacks on stacks of money saying ‚Äúget money for walking‚Äù. Nah fam. You get $1,000 if you walk 20k (about ten miles) every day for over a year. After 10k every day for a year, you can maybe afford a $50 gift card to nike, starbucks, or xbox. But that‚Äôs if it counts your steps. Now here‚Äôs where it gets fishy. This app started out working great, I was pulled in by the ads promising money, and though I was disappointed by the pretty hard to reach goals, I decided to give it a shot. It tracked my steps for the most part, but as of these past two weeks it just stopped counting my steps or only gave me half of the sweatcoins I‚Äôve earned. Yes, I have been walking outside. I walked 10k steps last week and got 5 swc. I walked 5k steps for the past week days and got none or 3 swc (only once). I don‚Äôt know what exactly is going on but if this doesn‚Äôt get fixed I‚Äôm gonna delete the app.
title: Pretty Cool at First But...

review: This app runs in the background of your phone, so you don‚Äôt even notice that you‚Äôre earning sweatcoins. You need to be committed to trying it out for more than a week, and collect the bonus each day, that way before you know it, you‚Äôre able to start actually buying things, sampling things or getting free first months of things instead of just a discount or a trial. There are also times I have to walk for work, and instead of going to an account 4 blocks down by car, I walk and know it will benefit me health wise and get me sweat coins. In less than one month, I‚Äôve already upgraded to the next level up and can earn 10 sweat coins per day. It costs 4.75 sweat coins a month, but I can earn that in 1-3 days by collecting the bonus anyways!  Works with Apple Watch and iPhone! Love this app.
title: Motivating when I don‚Äôt want to take an extra step

review:
I love this app. I got it a couple days ago and I‚Äôve been really lazy lately so it gives me motivation to walk more. But man, does it drain my battery. You guys should add portable chargers to the store because I need one right now. 

I know you added the low power mode, but the steps to verified steps ratio is so low that I can‚Äôt afford to miss out on any steps. Yesterday I walked 12,000 steps and it only calculated 4,500. I understand that you need to block out cheating but you say the percent of verified steps averages 65% yet I only have 30%. I use all the tips in the help  menu as well and use an IPhone X. 

I still love this app a lot. Most of the really nice offers will take at least two and a half years with the maximum walking limit plus the monthly charge, BUT if the steps I take are hardly counted then why even bother when it will take me 5 years at this rate to get 20,000 coins?
title: Great Incentive to walk! Step counting needs some work.

review: Instead of dreading walking around it the freezing cold or blistering hot weather, I can get paid to. This seems like a really good app and I hope it‚Äôll be in the future. I‚Äôve read some awfully mean comments on here and it‚Äôs sad because we‚Äôre all getting paid to walk! It‚Äôs a normal thing we do everyday, so instead of complaining be happy even if the app doesn‚Äôt count all your steps. Remember you weren‚Äôt getting paid before, so be grateful and stop nagging about all the problems. It‚Äôs an app meaning it‚Äôs not perfect and I‚Äôm sure the developers are working on improving it everyday. Just give them a break because they are super nice and generous by giving us this chance to earn a little money for walking and being active (which is good for your health, so essentially they‚Äôre also giving you a longer and healthier life).
title: I think this is a great app.

review: Got this app on my 14th and could not stop looking at it because it is so much fun because it‚Äôs like you‚Äôre owning real money but it‚Äôs on your phone but then you can go to the store and you can buy like iPhone or free music subscription and that is so cool I like this app I can‚Äôt believe that people are writing this terribly because I don‚Äôt understand what they‚Äôre talking about because this app is just totally awesome I encourage you to buy it because it is so awesomeü§© The app takes your steps and it calculates it into money that is stored on your phone until you put it onto my card will you buy something in the store such as like I said a gift card or a pair shoes on music to subscription or an iPhone either way by the app have so much fun and the fun thing is our good thing is that it has been improved so that it doesn‚Äôt take as much battery life.!
title: Awesome

review: So I downloaded this app a few days ago. I will review it again later (if possible) once I get more used to it. Someone I know recommended this app to me so I downloaded it. Now I logged in and of course I was pretty bummed to learn its only going to count my outdoor steps. So I brushed it off opened it and went about my day. Of course when I went to work I forgot to shut the app down... Now.. Im a Nursing Assistant so when I go to work I walk enough to put in a couple thousand steps there by itself let alone outside my work. So much to my amusement when I finally discovered that the app was actually still on.. it counted all the steps. Im pretty happy so. Im not sure why its counting my indoor steps but hey. Im glad it does Im happy that this app is working so well for me and Ive only had it two days now. Again, if I can I will write a review in a few months.

title: Great app for motivation

review:
This is app is pretty accurate (it generally shows the same number of steps that the iPhone Health app does), but when the steps are converted, it‚Äôs not unusual for it to reject 1,000 steps that I walked OUTSIDE. I walk to class, I generally walk maybe a hundred steps indoors the entire day, and just today the app rejected 800 steps. It‚Äôs been doing this more and more recently, and seems to be rejecting more as I get more sweatcoins. This app must think I‚Äôm cheating, because rejecting 800 steps in the matter of three hours is ridiculous.

EDIT: I have walked OUTSIDE, about 5,300 steps. Sweatcoins REJECTED 1,600 steps! This algorithm is clearly flawed if the app thinks I‚Äôve been shaking my phone to get those steps! If it actually read my GPS data, it would see that I‚Äôve walked between 1/2 a mile to mile in the walking spurts recorded by the iPhone Health app. I know it doesn‚Äôt sync with the app‚Äôs data, but maybe it should so that it‚Äôs ‚Äúcheating catcher‚Äù software is actually correct. This is honestly pretty infuriating, especially since the app was working pretty well until as of a few weeks ago.
title: Pretty accurate, but not perfect

title: Not anymore

review:
Sweat coin is not a very good app. It is very slow at counting your steps and even if you tried to get on a schedule of 10,000 steps a day it‚Äôs only going to count like 4000. But many people were interested because you actually get to buy stuff from getting enough sweat coins, but when I looked at the store the only stuff that was actually worth buying was really expensive stuff. title: Do Not Install

review: It‚Äôs just an Ad-Space? They‚Äôre pedaling you Ads. That‚Äôs it. That‚Äôs the game. It‚Äôs an app, where you log in, and all of their ‚Äúrewards‚Äù are free trials to companies who pay sweatcoin to promote their service. For example: ‚Äú$0.99 for 2 Months of Discovery+ for ONLY 10 SWEATCOINS!!‚Äù Wow! You mean the same deal Discovery+ literally gives ANYONE? How generous. The point is, the attainable ‚Äúprizes‚Äù they give you to choose from, are things you can already get, without sweatcoin. You are receiving NO benefits from this app unless you consider the motivation to walk lead by false promises an upside! Then maybe. The only way to get real ‚Äúprizes‚Äù on this app is to literally walk 10 years of your life with this app, considering you‚Äôll then even still remember the app, it hasn‚Äôt crashed, gone out of business, or didn‚Äôt count your total steps, then maybe, just maybe, you can get a lolipop after they‚Äôve already made thousands of dollars off of you by showing you ads every single day without you even knowing it.
title: Why would anyone get this?

review:
First off, this is a neat concept. Where this app fails is walking to earn Sweatcoins, to only use them for free trials on things you could get without even installing this app. The only thing that could potentially make this app worth it, is saving for 2-3 years of walking to finally get a ‚Äúmarathon‚Äù item, which usually costs 20,000 sweatcoins. Keep in mind, I am a foot patrol officer, and walk (according to this app) 20,000 steps a day, and only earn 4.35 sweat coins. Now my phone states I walk close to 55,000 steps a day. So the likelihood that this app will be worth it, is if your really that heart set on using this app everyday for 2-3 years to finally get something that costs real money. Otherwise all the lower price purchases are as simple as Google searching free trials or going to the companies main page and starting a new account to get exactly what you pay for in this app.

*Conclusion*
App is pretty pointless, you just buy free trials with your sweatcoins. It takes way to long to get something worth value.
title: Not really worth installing

review:

I can walk like 3000 steps and I will convert my steps but the line doesn‚Äôt go around the circle none. I can only make money for daily bonuses. It used to work but now it doesn‚Äôt. Until you fix it, it will stay that way. If someone could fix the app or at least tell me how‚Äôs to get rid of the problem or fix the problem that would be great.

-Marissaüíõ.
title: Where are my sweatcoins?

review: Just because you are inside doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre steps won‚Äôt be counted. The algorithm they use is designed to make sure you are actually moving and insures that the steps that get counted are the ones that do your body good. Almost all of my steps at work count! If you work in a large building, go up and down long hallways, run on an indoor track, or walk through a mall. You‚Äôre steps will most likely count. Do you get in a lot of steps at work? Are you always on your feet and moving at a reasonable pace? Most of those steps should qualify. I consider lots of steps to be above the 10,000 daily recommended. If you just walking from desk to printer or bathroom and couch to kitchen those won‚Äôt register. But if you‚Äôre walking across a warehouse or up and down hospital hallways most of them will.
title: Don‚Äôt be fooled by indoor/outdoor steps

review:
I used Sweatcoin years ago back when it was bare bones and had no ads. I stopped using it because most of my exercise back then involved rowing, which wasn‚Äôt being picked up by the app nor my Fitbit, so I just didn‚Äôt see the point in continuing at the time. 

Fast forward to present day. I rejoined Sweatcoin on September 16, 2023. I walked 10,625 steps the day I rejoined, and not one single coin was given to me for all of those steps. NOT. ONE. I marched in a parade, walked all over my town for a festival that was being held that day. The app itself even shows me that it knows I walked 10,625 steps that day, and yet for some reason I never received credit for those steps.

Not to mention all of the insufferable ads you have to watch now, ads for scam apps. I once thought Sweatcoin was reputable, but seeing those slimy ads and the fact my steps on my very first day weren‚Äôt credited, I think it is inevitable that I will once again discontinue use of this app.
title: Great idea, poor execution

review: I‚Äôve had sweatcoin for probably about a month, and all I‚Äôve made is 21 dollars. But the worst part is, is that you can‚Äôt even take the money out of your sweatcoin account and then have it to spend on whatever you want with physical cash. You have to keep the money you have earned in your account, so you never actually have earned the money. If you ever delete the app, then you lose all of your money and progress. I just tried to get a bark box for my dog, because I earned enough money, thinking that if I payed for it in sweatcoin I would get a box free or something.  I had to pay to see what the deal actually was, and they made me go through a whole bark box transaction before I realized that I only got 50% off my first bark box. It was basically a giant add for barkbox. They didn‚Äôt explain well enough what I was buying. Now, I only have 9 dollars in my account.
title: You don‚Äôt ACTUALLY get the money

review: See on my behalf I‚Äôm not able to get the cash by itself..that‚Äôs what they need to work on because I don‚Äôt wanna keep buying rewards on there when I still have to take my money from my card to use it to be shipped to my house..why can‚Äôt y‚Äôall go ahead and set up the cash card or something that lets you put your sweat coins into your card or have us transfer the sweatcoin money to our debit cards or something..people are not gonna get interested in it if all they doin is walk and using it to buy rewards..some people need that money for helping out there children and buying food and actually buying things that are important without having to go online and look for things..people don‚Äôt have money to pay for hair and hair products and clothes because we can‚Äôt transfer the money to a card.. it doesn‚Äôt make since to me at allüëéüèæüëéüèæüëéüèæüëéüèæüëéüèæsorry but I won‚Äôt use it again until they update this app to where we can‚Äôt transfer the money to a card ( an actual card )
title: The cash

review: This app is boo-boo. I have been using it for over 6 months and racked up about 350 sweat coins since. Keep in mind I am a 22 y/o and active. Would mostly use this indoors at my last job and it does work indoors although you will lose some steps. My problem with this is the offers they have do not change much. If I put a number on how many different offers they have had in my six months using it, I would be nice and appreciative and say maybe 18 or less offers. Most of them are a few dollars off of websites you have never heard of with decent product but no credibility really. Some are good for people like me like the fitness workout plan, but its mostly basic streetwear and some jewelry, and also some food products. Not worth killing your battery and ‚Äúgrinding‚Äù for sweat coins for most likely over a year to get a $50 gift card, which you would have to use it EVERY DAY. The developers need to market their app more and get more companies to put their products on here.
title: Same offer ALL THE TIME

review:
I used Sweatcoin years ago, and recently downloaded it again since I started going for walks again. The app says for every 1,000 steps, you get 1 Sweatcoin (capped at 10 Sweatcoins per day with the free plan). I walked 12,000 steps and was given 2 Sweatcoins. This is not an accident and is a daily occurrence. The rewards have also been massively downgraded, where you can buy measly 10% discounts for overpriced small businesses. Years ago, they had actual items in the shop (vacations, phones, walking shoes). They‚Äôve also fallen into the classic method of crypto scamming app users, pressuring you into converting your steps into a worthless $SWEAT coin. There are many other apps that actually reward you for your walking, but nowadays this app just screams scammy.

In response to the developer response:
I can update my settings all day to work with this app, but it still won‚Äôt fix the issue you caused. You‚Äôre well aware that the app does not give credit for the full amount of steps.

If you continue to encounter issues, please let us know!", 'modified': '2020-03-05T12:54:05Z'}
review: The app does NOT give you all your steps. It shorts you so much it‚Äôs ridiculous. Only recently have the steps registered more correctly, but still not completely. My main concern with this app is that it tells you that if you have it in the background with your GPS hooked up to it, it will convert your steps automatically, however what they don‚Äôt tell you is that you have to manually open the app every morning as well as convert the steps every so often, then what is the point of telling the users that it will do it for you? It won‚Äôt actually do it for you. I know this to be fact because I‚Äôll forget to open the app in the mornings, so all the steps I took the day before convert to 0 SWC dollars  the day after. The steps DO NOT roll over to the next day. Which okay maybe I can understand if they would convert by the end of the same day which, again üòíüò†üò°üò§, they don‚Äôt. Fix this problem ASAP. I don‚Äôt need you the developers or whoever responds to these reviews to respond to mine. All I ask is that you fix this issue.
title: Terrible plain and simple

review: First off, this app is ENTIRELY free. It is made for your benefit, and you‚Äôll get out of it what you put into it. If you‚Äôre not walking as much too earn the offers you want, then just keep it running in the background and keep moving! The Sweatcoin team has an amazing vision of giving us products and rewarding us for staying active. The hard truth is too much of America is obese and not nearly active enough, including me. This app keeps me motivated, and maybe one day I can get one of those vacations or new phones from investing in my health! I‚Äôve had this app for years & recommend it to more people than I can count. Thank you so much Sweatcoin Team for you hard work! I will gladly be one of the startup supporters of this company :) I can‚Äôt wait to see what it becomes.
title: Awesome App!!! Great Job!

review: This app does wonders, I thought it would be just another one of those scam apps where you put in more money and receive less. But how wrong I was.. Not only does this app pay you to go out and walk or jog, but it‚Äôs free in the App Store, FREEEEEE!! Others might say it‚Äôs a waste of time and that‚Äôs their opinion so obviously we can‚Äôt just change their mindset in one minute with some little review. But the real purpose is to let them know about it hoping that one day they‚Äôll get this app that could win them rewards and so much more. SweatCoin isn‚Äôt a full time job haha, but it‚Äôs still an easy and efficient way to get in shape whilst earning coins to purchase market items. Check it out if you want to get rewarded for taking care of your physical healthü§©

review:
This is a good app. It gives money for walking but I have a lot of sweat coins and I can‚Äôt do anything with it. I want to cash out but why did the app have to make it so that I have to invite people. I keep stacking sweat coin and I can‚Äôt use it. If you are not an influencer you can‚Äôt cash out or do anything with it than wait for something cool in the shop that you want. I think the app should make it so that you get sweatcoins when you invite so that people will want invite others to get more sweatcoins. 

Having to invite people in order to cash out is making me less motivated to walk or even use the app because I know that I won‚Äôt be able to use the money even after I walked a lot. I wish that the developers will change it so that you don‚Äôt have to invite people to cash out and you can make the paypal cash out for 5$, 10$  50 and 75 sweat coin to motivate people to walk more to get the 10$. I don‚Äôt think the developers will see this but if they do please alter the rules of cashing out to make it easier
title: Invites

review:
I have had this app for almost 1 year. 
I have not purchased anything as of yet and I have 850 sweat coins. 
What lured me to this app was my brother and at the time there was an option to spend 20,000 sweat coins for a $1,000 PayPal card. 
Unfortunately that is no longer an option... and I checked today.. and anything left that i could ‚Äúpurchase‚Äù is sold out... and the $1,000 PayPal is no longer available. 
They do, however, have an option for charities.... which is cool and all... but they cost LITERALLY 8 MILLION sweat coins...
You would literally have to have this app for 10 YEARS to even get close to earning that much. 
I have read developers comments on the reviews about updating their process to track steps you take... (they have your Apple Watch step counts and you literally could only get rewarded for 50 steps after taking 3k...) but I still have not seen a difference. 
My boyfriend does not have an Apple phone and he deleted the app because we spent all summer hiking 5-15 mile hikes a day and after the summer he only had $120!!!! 
You don‚Äôt have to pay anything for this app... you just have to walk outside. So for that I‚Äôm not complaining.. but what they advertise and what actually happens and is available is not really worth it in my opinion. 
If I didn‚Äôt have an iPhone X with 256gb of storage... this app would have been gone a long time ago.
title: Too much

review: I‚Äôve had this app for years now and have gotten many things with it including wireless earbuds that I use daily. However it seems that in the past few months no matter what time of day I check or what the product is, the pay with sweatcoins section is ALWAYS out of stock. I‚Äôm not exaggerating one bit. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve seen and item in stock in that section for months and months and it‚Äôs ridiculous. The only other option I have to use my sweatcoins is to go to the sections where shipping isn‚Äôt free or it‚Äôs only a discount and if the items in the pay with sweatcoins section keep being out of stock i may as well delete the app. And they say out of stock when only around 50 people claimed the products. Please fix this!
title: One proble

review: This is app is honestly great. The only thing I harmve an issue with, is that it‚Äôs a bit buggy, which might sound odd given that I‚Äôm only giving the app 3 stars. But when I say buggy, I mean it says I‚Äôve walked, 378 steps, it‚Äôs only counted 110, and it says I have no more uncounted steps and I can‚Äôt force update it. So I‚Äôm confused, does the app think I‚Äôm cheating or something‚Äôs acting up, and there is no answer to this in the app forums. I also feel like there should be no cap on how much you move per day if the apps truely to get people up and moving, what the subscriptions should be is the more expensive your subscription is the more you make per 1k steps. So mover would be 0.10 and shaker 0.15 and Quaker 0.20 and so on and so fourth, or male mover 0.05 so that it‚Äôs a bit more balanced and you guys don‚Äôt loose a ton of money. I just am writing this about my dislikes with the glitches and my suggestions on the subscriptions. Have a good one!
title: Needs some...work

review:
This app advocates that the more steps you take, the more money you get from it. Sounds good... until you realize it takes a week to make 2 dollars (Over 35K steps) and the shop items are very limited. The good stuff (like $1000 in paypal, a TV. etc.) can‚Äôt be bought until you have walked for almost 2 years, and there is nothing in between. You can get money off of purchases for very cheap but they aren‚Äôt always what you want at all. There is nothing in between things that are worth $5 and things that are worth $1000, which is VERY frustrating. There should be things in between, like $20 gift cards after one month of walking, or $100 gift cards after 5 months. It is very unrewarding.

To fix these problems: Raise the rate of SWC gain OR lower the cost of the big stuff OR/AND add things in between.

Thank you.
title: Not bad but very low income and way too expensive rewards

review:
The only possible way to actually get paid money for walking, like the app advertises, is by reaching 20,000 sweatcoins and trading them for $1,000. This is a great concept, but the app limits you harshly to ensure that you never reach that goal. First of all, they limit the amount of sweatcoins you can earn in a day to 20. You can take 100,000 steps but the app will only give you 20 sweatcoins, the equivalent of 25,000 steps taken. 
They also have a sweatcoin transfer feature where your friends with the app can send you sweatcoins that they‚Äôve earned. Sounds like you can meet your goals twice as fast if you have a friend walking along with you, right? Wrong. You cannot used transferred sweatcoins towards the cash reward. It‚Äôs clear that this app does not want us to actually win money by walking. They hope that people use their app every day and they try to make it take so long to get paid that you just give up before getting there.
This is scam artistry.
title: Impossible to reach worthwhile goals

review: When my friend mention this I laugh no kidding. Then I saw some interesting things you can redeem with your steps you do per day. The free ver is only 5 dolors limit or 5000 steps Limit the others are 5 dollars more but it‚Äôs a month free trial which not bad since I walk like 10 thousand steps just now. And downloaded this app literally last night and morning I went outside. Batter saver good however there an issue on not counting the total steps. It drains a lot battery I will say from 70 percent from 35 percent for 8 hours outside. I work outdoors so I walk a lot. This app really makes you want walk more. I mean who wouldn‚Äôt want earn free money for walking. This pretty cool also I still haven‚Äôt redeem anything since a lot offers require a lot points or money so I‚Äôll be saving them till I find a good offer or just save them for year see how much I make.
title: Pretty neat to walk and get paid lol

review: So this is a great way to track your steps but not so much the gift cards part. They are constantly out of stock and only give away at max 3 different gift cards that all sell out on the same day. Good luck trying to get one. I have money to get a card but have not had a chance to purchase anything. They have bidding which is great however peopme enter with MULTIPLE profiles that have the same account however different step numbers. You can always donate though. However, definitely disappointed and bumbed out that there is never really gift cards or physical products you can get. Sure you have 50% off of a store or 20% off but they are stores that of not frequently used and I have never heard the name of some of these companies. I have used this app several times through the years as I work healthcare and am always walking on my feet and this app has had this issue for a while now.
title: Eh..not all that

review: I don‚Äôt like this recent upgrade where you can‚Äôt use the sweat coins you earned to upgrade the amount of steps you can get in a day. Now you have to use your own money for it. And the prizes are never good to get or are sold out instantly. I can check back a few minutes after the shop updates and everything good is sold out immediately. Let me trade my sweat coins for gift cards or something. I‚Äôm about to delete the app because there‚Äôs no incentive anymore besides watching how many steps I take in a day. But every company is about making more money these days and not about customer happiness. There‚Äôs other apps that can count my steps plus other features without lying to their customers. They don‚Äôt claim to ‚Äúpay for walking‚Äù they are a lot more trustworthy than this app has ever been. I‚Äôve had this app for years and saved up over 4K coins. But it‚Äôs not worth it when I can‚Äôt buy anything, at that point it‚Äôs just a step counter that only goes up to 10k
title: Used to be good

review: Only rating 5 stars so people see this review. I‚Äôve had this app for over a year and barely have 600 coins. I‚Äôve worked a job where I‚Äôm constantly moving and have barely built up coins during this time. Not only that but any of the ‚Äúgood‚Äù products that you can buy with coins are always ‚Äúout of stock‚Äù even when it shows there are ‚Äúhowever many‚Äù left, it never lets me buy anything because it still will end up saying out of stock. I even made sure to try and constantly check to be one of the first to buy. So, the only other thing you‚Äôre left with are getting discounts on just genuinely not great programs. Not worth it to me. Just a scam for them to partner with other companies to get you to sign up for memberships.
title: Scam

review:
It‚Äôs a great idea and if you get enough coins, awesome way to get cool prizes. As far as everyday use and generating those coins? Not ideal. I am a student and live off campus so I walk EVERYWHERE. My part-time job also consists of me walking a lot in outdoor areas. The app usually reads about half of these steps and from those, maybe counts 1/3 of those?

 For example, I walked about 15-20,000 steps today as it was a long day. Sweatcoins detected 9,000 and awarded me $0.00. This happens pretty often and continues with updates. I usually leave it running in the background and am SLOWWWLLYYY building up coins. So in all? Cool app, cool idea, but it‚Äôs hard to really get anywhere with how strict the algorithm is (which is understandable). Hopefully the developers are able to improve on this soon and everyone can gain more coins and win cool prizes! For now, though, I‚Äôll just let it passively build up and check it every few months.
title: Cool idea, doesn‚Äôt work out well

review: I‚Äôm really conflicted over this app, lol. I want to like it, but when I do the daily rewards I always get like .5 and it‚Äôs ridiculous...I can‚Äôt remember to turn the app on every time I head out the door so not only are steps not being converted properly due to the app‚Äôs faults, but without the app running constantly I can‚Äôt get steps counted. Also, everything is outrageously pricey. I‚Äôve seen some people say it took them 2 years just to get a reward valued at $6, and everything I see made available is thousands to billions of sweat coins?! That would take..just forever. It‚Äôs fine if you consider you‚Äôre ‚Äúearning‚Äù something just for walking, although really you aren‚Äôt earning a thing until YEARS later, but I mean, you can‚Äôt set a goal to work towards obtaining a certain reward..by the time you‚Äôd have the coins the reward would be long gone. I don‚Äôt know, I think I may just end up removing the app. It‚Äôs disappointing because the concept is awesome but the execution is crap.
title: Torn

review:
I was quite literally sitting on the couch when I saw an ad for this app. It‚Äôs been a couple weeks since I got my air cast off from breaking my ankle and the surgeon told me to strengthen it back up the best thing to do was to simply walk. I haven‚Äôt done much of that except yard work or grocery shopping. As soon as I set this app up, I walked inside and then outside to see if it worked properly and it does. I got dressed and went on a half hour walk! I am now icing my ankle (lol) but I‚Äôm happy I got outside for some exercise.

The only 2 complaints I have is it said 0 of 8 invites sent after I had sent out 10, so it didn‚Äôt calculate that properly, however, I just had someone sign up and I got a notification for it. I also wish it counted steps inside as my husband walks a ton at work all day which would be very beneficial to him!

Great app though so far!
title: Great motivator

review:
I have had this app for over 5 years. I was lured by the ability to collect coins from walking and running outside, with the possibility of getting cool prizes.  I now have over 18,000 Sweatcoins.  You can get discounts on junkie items, but the app offers the same discounts you can get anywhere on the Internet without downloading an app that tracks all your data.  You ‚Äúthink‚Äù there are offers for gift cards.  That is a total scam.  I have been checking multiple times per day for years to see when a gift card is available, and the answer is NEVER.  SOLD OUT.  SOLD OUT.  SOLD OUT.  Really?  Am I that unlucky, or is it a scam?  

You can collect Sweatcoin from watching 3 ads per day.  Most of the ads are from Chinese game manufacturers that claim they are endorsed by major celebrities and PayPal.  Google ‚ÄúOprah endorsement scam‚Äù.  These are the kinds of ads you will see.

I have a friend at PayPal and he said they are constantly suing companies like Sweatcoin for using their likeness without their permission.  They DO NO give permission to use their likeness in video games.

The last item of note is you can donate your Sweatcoin to causes.  In my cynical mind, these are probably scams, as well.

Protect your data.  Save your time.  Don‚Äôt waste it on this data-tracking app.  It‚Äôll save some of your battery life as well as this needs to be open at all times to count.  There is no prize at the end of the tunnel.
title: Almost a Scam

review:
PRO: The app works good for counting steps and it is true, you get to use sweatcoins towards actual purchases which is great

CON: Unfortunately, I‚Äôve yet to see an item worth having not be labeled ‚Äúsold out‚Äù. It seems everything but digital items is labeled ‚Äúsold out‚Äù. This makes me think there isn‚Äôt actual things to spend your coins on. The digital items, which are easily available, seem to either be referral items which ‚Äúsweatcoins‚Äù earns off you, or free trials and things which are available directly from said sight or through other means. I bought a chevron gift card labeled up to 50% off, it was clearly the same offer I could‚Äôve downloaded from the linked site, and it was only 35% off anyways. 

Long story short, if sweatcoins offered more, it‚Äôd be worth it for giving them your personal information. As of now, I couldn‚Äôt recommend them if you are looking for rewards.
title: Rewards almost non existent

review:
This app rewards you for steps tracked by your phone. It doesn‚Äôt always reward you for all the steps logged, and seems inconsistent at times in rewarding coins accordingly.

Also essentially all the ‚Äúrewards‚Äù are from obscure companies that look like their websites were made on square space, and only sell dropshipped items. Usually you can find similar goods on AliExpress for the same price as shipping on these websites. Also most of the time the ‚Äúrewards‚Äù are only discounts to severely marked up products anyway.

They do now offer a premium section for rewards, which has a membership fee, and doesn‚Äôt seem to offer much better in the ways of compensation besides slightly less cheap garbage. Overall seems a big scam and pretty worthless if you think you‚Äôll actually gain anything from using the app. Best thing to do with your coins is donate them on charity drives they have on here since the rewards are no better than scholastic book fair toys you‚Äôd buy as a kid in school.
title: Dropship Galore

review: i like the app, i haven‚Äôt bought anything on it and currently i‚Äôve got almost two hundred sweatcoins. i‚Äôve had the app over a year, and there still isn‚Äôt a way to transfer sweatcoins into a bank account or something like that. there isn‚Äôt a way to get any actual money from this app. the only thing you can do is spend it on the offers in the app, and all the offers either cost thousands of sweatcoins, or are the same thing over and over again. like that calm app and subscriptions to workout things on your tv. it‚Äôs ridiculous. there needs to be a way to get actual money from this app, or this app is pointless. it‚Äôs wasting my battery, not counting all my steps, and not giving me anything i would want to spend my sweatcoins on. the app is semi trash and not worth getting. Sweatcoin developers - give us a way to receive actual money from this app, or ur app will go down hill.
title: good but not the best

review: This app literally cheats. I decided to go on a walk and try to get the most amount of money you can get in a day. So I was planning to go on a walk up in till I was at 5.00 sweatcoins ‚Äúthe halfway point‚Äù then turn around and come back and get my other 5.00 sweatcoins, the thing was the first half I had my phone on the whole time And kept on refreshing it. When I got to my have way point my phone‚Äôs battery was low so I turned off my phone because It‚Äôs still supposed to track the steps you take by the time I came back I wasn‚Äôt even close to getting the full amount of steps. I understand that the steps you take are not going to be the exact same there and back but it was like way to far off. title: Bad

review: I like this app because, even though I try not to bring my phone everywhere with me, the idea of meeting a daily goal or a weekly/monthly step average provides an incentive to take the stairs, park in the back of the lot, go for a walk, run another lap, etc. It's a fun way to keep track of my habits and improve them. I have also gotten some cool stuff from it. It doubles as an advertising platform for startups which I guess is cool. I'm not much of a consumer but I've tried stuff I wouldn't have otherwise tried because of the offers on sweatcoin. It's fun. I also like the new daily bonus format because it encourages the user to at least hit 2,000 steps each day. My job is sedentary, so it helps me get up and move to get coin. Overall, cool.
title: Incentivizes walking

developerResponse: {'id': 18599493, 'body': 'Hi!\nThanks for your review!\nWe have always had a combination of products that can be bought entirely for sweatcoins and some products where you get a discount that is higher than anything else you can find on the market. We, of course, strive to bring you unparalleled value for your steps and sometimes it is not an entirely free product but a very deep discount on a thing that someone would not buy otherwise. If you see some place where you can get a better deal for your steps please please please let us know - we learn fast and for sure will find the way to get you an equal or even a better deal. Happy Sweatcoining!!!', 'modified': '2020-10-20T15:51:09Z'}
review: Being rewarded for your steps and time to watch adds is always something that people look forward to, but I‚Äôm this app rewards work a little differently. I have only had the app for maybe 2 months now and from what I‚Äôve seen the app gives you ‚Äúoffers‚Äù based on your sweat coins earned and you can ‚Äúbuy‚Äù these offers using your coins. The issue I am seeing is that some offers are available off the app and for free (0 sweat coins) or have shipping costs that would get you the same product if you just went to the store and spent the money yourself (aka shipping cost is more or less equal to actual product cost). This being said I do not think this app is worth the space and batter that it consumes while on your phone. If the app changes and the ‚Äúoffers‚Äù or rewards get better I would be happy to change my review but as it stands this 2/5 star rating is accurate in my opinion.
title: Good idea, poor execution

review:
Okay, the part of where you close out the app, it text you for doing that. Part of my problem is, if I got to sleep. Why do I need the app to be open for sleeping at night. Add a button to the app, going to sleep. 
Two, it drains my iPhone battery a lot faster, whin I got it open. So got to charge up more in the day time, like at my job. 

Three, you should add more to the profile, like what kind of job you got. I am a housekeeper at a hospital and on my feet all day. But in side more to as well. I hit about 20,000 a day in step for my job. How about the guy that set behind a desk all day, would be motivated to get up and go walk. 
Someone that a, firefighter, police officer, Forest ranger, our any job outside. Would get more step out side, but someone side,  Will not get a lot outside steps and to busy as will.
title: Cool

developerResponse: {'id': 11311932, 'body': 'Hi Winnestasia!\nKeep in mind the offers change every day, so you just need to keep an eye out for one you like :) If you have any suggestions for us, let us know on our forum at community.sweatco.in', 'modified': '2019-10-17T16:41:04Z'}
review:
I‚Äôve had this app for over 2 years. I‚Äôve accumulated  830 sweatcoins. The actual products that you can purchase are always either sold out or beyond overpriced in sweatcoins. I‚Äôm talking over 5,000 sweatcoins. All other products are deceiving. They offer you to pay X amount of sweatcoins for a Discount on a product. Typically a subscription service like Bark Box or a music streaming service. It‚Äôs so frustrating seeing all the adds online of that guy saying ‚ÄúI bought these shoes with only sweatcoins‚Äù. I‚Äôve never seen a product like that available unless you are able to walk marathons on a regular basis and accumulate thousands of sweatcoins easily. 

The app also closes randomly and when you open it it states that sweatcoins were lost. I‚Äôve never closed the app. I‚Äôve probably missed out on so many sweatcoins for that reason. 

This app isn‚Äôt worth your data or your time. Don‚Äôt download it unless they actually start offering good products at a reasonable price 100% for sweatcoins.
title: It‚Äôs just a discount app for subscription products.

review: Sweatcoin doesn‚Äôt use the steps your phone counts automatically, but tries to count your steps itself. Also, you can‚Äôt walk on a treadmill or any kind of workout machine. You actually have to be moving from place to place outside, which is understandable as it‚Äôs trying to keep people from cheating, but it would be nice to use on a treadmill. The app wants you to keep it open and let it run in the background, and is terrible for your battery life. It‚Äôs not going to offer you credits to use at your own will, but to use on deals that the app offers itself. There are occasionally some neat products and deals that Sweatcoin offers. Although, if the app sends you a notification that there‚Äôs an interesting product, it‚Äôs likely already sold out. Other times, when you see a deal you like and click on it to try to get it, it won‚Äôt load. In my experience, Sweatcoin has been a waste of time, and battery life.
title: Interesting concept, just not done well

review: I‚Äôve only had this app for a day, but I think it‚Äôs pretty great. The whole system of the sweatcoins being able to be transferred to actual prizes is pretty amazing. This app gives you actual motivation to get out of the house and exercise. The only thing that I wish could be changed is sweatcoins being able to be directly transferred to a bank account. This would make things a lot easier than having to browse offers all the time, and have to pay things like shipping, or worry about canceling the subscription after your free one has run out. I think that being able to see the actual money that you have made from exercising right in front of you would be really cool. I mean, in my first day I would‚Äôve already make a dollar, and I only walked for like 30 mins. (1 sweatcoin is about the same as 3 cents)
title: This app is pretty cool

review: hey so this app is pretty great with the sweatcoins. It does it in the background so you don‚Äôt have to actually be on the app to do it so that‚Äôs good. and then when you go on the app your like ‚Äúwoah I didn‚Äôt even realize I got that much‚Äù. however when your buying with the coins nothing is free. the product itself is, but when the shipping is 20+ dollars which is more than the actual product itself then we have a problem. so then after you buy the item you can‚Äôt get those coins back even if you never actually purchase the item. so you‚Äôll waste so much money for nothing. lastly I accidentally pushed a different country, so I can‚Äôt buy stuff from the us and now instead it‚Äôs somewhere in Europe and I can‚Äôt change it, the products are way less motivating to get and the shipping is way more expensive because it has to ship over seas. Please fix this stuff or the apps not worth it at all.
title: fees

review:
I may be old fashioned, but the thing that ticked me off the most about this app was the eye-rolling or stun-faced emojis and patronizing text the app would use any time you did or thought of doing something it didn‚Äôt like (like force-quitting it or having it analyze your steps right away ‚Äúif you‚Äôre impatient.‚Äù Don‚Äôt belittle your clients. Find a respectful way to entreat them to do what you want.

Also, I doubt it will ever count indoor steps because it is about getting you to watch ads more than it is about getting you to walk. That said, I probably would have kept it longer, since it wasn‚Äôt hurting anything to have it running, but I couldn‚Äôt take the app‚Äôs attitude. Too annoying and not enough reward worth it. I gave it 2 stars because it does allow you to donate any amount to charity. It does not tell you how much in real money is being donated (pennies, probably), but I trust it is actually doing some good. But I‚Äôm done. Thanks, and goodbye.
title: Belittling and No Indoor Steps Count

review: Hello! I love your app! I use it every day and it helps me a lot. A few things I would change though is how fast you get SweatCoins, and how many SweatCoins you get for a certain amount of steps. A main thing I would change is how much stuff costs because to get the IPhone XS you would have to walk miles, and miles, and miles! The last thing I would change is finding friends. If I were you I would make it so you can find friends by searching names instead of searching contacts and make it so those friends you might not know can‚Äôt get information on your account. They should also be able to send you SweatCoins because I know some people who have bought an IPhone XS off your app! thanks for taking the time to read this if you did! Hope it helped everyone reading this get an understanding of the app and complaints I have..that includes you to people who made SweatCoin!

title: Cheats you

I haven‚Äôt been able to purchase anything or get anything because it‚Äôs always sold out. Idk if anyone else has that problem but I do. Do I need to be on the app 24/7 to get to things first? That genuinely confuses me I just don‚Äôt understand. Other than that this app is good but the step to coin generator is broken. I walk 1000 steps I get a couple of cents instead of 1 coin/dollar. title: Hear me out

Waking my dog I like to use the boost because we walk for 30 minutes in the mornings. I have noticed that even when I see the steps reach 2198, (2200 needed for the 5 sweat pins) the steps are miscalculated at the end. When I know the steps are calculated much better outside. I‚Äôve had a enough of this app. I‚Äôm going to take the remainder of my sweat coins and donate them to a charity. Then delete my account and app. It‚Äôs not worth the hassle, to have the same app for years that supposedly works in the background, but have yet to reach across the 2000s in sweatcoins.

review: The prizes and offers are really cool, and it‚Äôs a fun way to exercise, but it has its flaws. So, I have had the app for about two weeks, and it was fine. But then it started to glitch and whenever I would just exit out the app and walk ( since according to the app you don‚Äôt need to have it open ), it would say that I force quitted it and all the steps I got showed up on the ‚Äú today‚Äôs total steps ‚Äú but it wouldn‚Äôt  send me any money/sweat coins. So I had basically lost all my steps for no reason. Also, for the offers, things are really cheap, but shipping costs like 20 sweat coins. Lastly, the step algorithm is really bad. I just walked about 3,000 steps today, and it is only giving me like 15 cents/ sweat coins. So just like another review I saw, I might consider deleting the app unless they fix their stupid algorithm, lower shipping costs, and fix the stupid glitch. Then I might actually recommend the app to people. But right now, if you already have the app keep it, but if you are looking to download it, DON‚ÄôT.
title: It‚Äôs not the best app

review: I‚Äôve had this app for pretty close to two years now and walking steadily pretty much daily I‚Äôve only managed to accumulate around 2600 sweatcoins. I walk a lot and to see the slow growth towards being able to cash out the coins; (20,000swc for $1000 PayPal) I‚Äôll have to be walking for 6 more years to ever see any real payout... I love the app and the whole idea of generating currency for walking but between the slow growth and not counting indoor steps, (10-15k a day at work) it can be a little demotivating. Today for example I‚Äôve walked 20,324 steps and only made 8.82swc. Lowering the conversion rate would definitely generate more interest from people towards your app and I hope that one day you guys will finally be able to make SWC a cryptocurrency like has been stated in the help section for as long as I can remember.
title: Great idea, wish the payout was a little more.

review: I see some of the frustrations people are mentioning in their reviews: affect on the battery, actual outside steps not being counted, the difficulty in reaching the goals to buy market items. I have looked at the count as I exited the house to go on a long weekend hike. So I ‚Äúknew‚Äù it didn‚Äôt give me credit for at least a thousand steps. That seems to be the case most days. Even though that is frustrating, I choose to see it as a motivation to do an extra 1k of steps. I am walking anyway to improve my health....so anything I get as a perk or reward is nice. I do wish the app wouldn‚Äôt shut down by itself so often. I need to frequently check it and re-open the app so I won‚Äôt walk a mile without it being counted. All things considered I like it very much. I‚Äôm hoping that when it‚Äôs time to cash in my coins I will have a positive experience.
title: Good so far

review: The idea behind this app is great. And I completely understand that not all steps get counted because the algorithm used has to make sure that you aren‚Äôt just shaking your phone and cheating to get steps.  I‚Äôm sure the algorithm is getting better, but I‚Äôm not sure why indoor steps don‚Äôt count.  If my phone can track my movement from one side of the building to the other side, I don‚Äôt see why the app says that wouldn‚Äôt generate coins or usable steps.  Also some of the user interface is a little frustrating. Updating the app is ridiculously difficult because it can‚Äôt update while the app is actively running and when I quit the app it actively starts running again to try to track steps.  If there was a way to make sure the application would update correctly, that would be great. Because it always takes me three or four days to get a new update to update.
title: Great idea, needs more tuning

review: I like the app in general üòï! However, the advertisements that it uses is utterly ridiculous!! Why can‚Äôt the advertisement just ‚ÄúEND‚Äù after it finishes playing. But nooooooooo it‚Äôll stop‚Ä¶..then you have to press ‚ÄúDONE‚Äù then the music will play for another 15 seconds or so. Then you hit the arrow and it‚Äôll play more music (if you didn‚Äôt touch any space outside of the arrow and it didn‚Äôt start over) then the ‚ÄúX‚Äù will finally pop up!!! title: Ridiculous!

review:
This app is a joke. It offers you several tantalizing prizes mixed in with mundane ones (that I doubt anyone wants), however, it is impossible to obtain the large prizes.
 
 Take for instance the $1000 PayPal credit. In order to obtain this reward, you must allocate 20,000 sweatcoins. 1,000 steps equals 1 sweatcoin, however the app has a cap of 5 sweatcoins per day (and to increase the cap, you need to pay monthly payments). As a result, in order to obtain one of the desirable prizes, you must walk 5,000 steps everyday for the next 11 years.
  
  I respect the idea behind this app, rewarding those who will walk, however, it is clear that this expression of this idea is one that will fail to capture its own goal due to its impossible rewards. If the developers of this app wish for this app to succeed, they need to implement more short term desirable rewards such as $5 gift cards. I understand that the developers need to create a profit, but please, make at least more obtainable rewards.
title: Won‚Äôt help you at all.

review:
I have been using this app all year and have accrued a few hundred sweatcoins. I'm after the big prizes, so I don't spend my coins on the promos in the market unless it's something I know will be useful (like a free month of Calm). I do think some of their promos are really interesting, though. 

I LOVE that sweatcoin now has crowdfunding campaigns that I can donate my coins to. I get extra coins for doing the daily ad bonus, so I will now donate most of those. I think I like donating to these causes more than I like saving coins for a big prize. It feels good to help other people.

My only issue with the app is that it does not accurately track my steps. I regularly take 2-mile walks, but sweatcoin often counts 2/3 my steps or less. I know because I compare to other health apps that all show the full distance of my walk. I would like this app to count all my steps so I can earn & donate more coins. 

I have a suggestion for the developers: it would be awesome to let sweatcoin track my steps when I go to the gym. Perhaps you could use the GPS to have location-specific check-ins at gyms all over the country. Earning sweatcoins for gym cardio would motivate me to both donate sweatcoin & go to the gym more often.
title: Sweatcoin

title: Quality of prizes decreasing

review: I downloaded this app thinking it would correlate directly with the health/fitness apps I already use. With every step you take, you earn ‚Äúin app currency‚Äù and can put that towards charities/giveaways. Seemed really cool and I figured an awesome way to bring me motivation to walk more than I already do. The first couple of days of having the app, it counted a majority of my steps. I‚Äôd get in around 7,000 in one of my days and it would take in around 4,000. I don‚Äôt expect accuracy so that‚Äôs fine. But after those first three days the steps it counted went down drastically, I‚Äôm talking I‚Äôd get in around 6,000 on a slower day and the app would only count 130 or so. I went out and walked a couple miles thinking maybe it would only measure exercise - it counted maybe 50 steps out of a five mile walk, that should‚Äôve been roughly around 10,000 steps. Am I missing something here? I let the app sync to all my other fitness/health apps and still it‚Äôs measurements are so far off it‚Äôs almost hysterical.
title: Five mile walk in 50 steps...

review: Great idea for an app!!  Now we need honest people to build it.  This group is not honest.  The algorithm for this app is very devious.  Let me explain.  I am a Mailman.  My phone tells me everyday that I walk over 10,000 steps a day.  Some days a lot more if I have to do part of another route.  My route does not get smaller or bigger.  Should be no less than 400 step difference every day.  Not with this app.  Sometimes it is an 800 to 1200 difference usually in the negative.  But my final straw was last night.  Day off yesterday so yeah my steps will greatly reduce. I sat down and had 2900 and some change.  I minimized it and played my turn on some games.  When I went back I only had 2300.  I lost 600 steps?  Guess they thought I would not notice.  So please if there are any honest app builders out there remake this.  I will be the first in line to download it.  To the current apps owners.  Y‚Äôall need to either quit trying to become millionaires over night at our expense and do the right thing!  Dishonest pukes.  -App is Deleted-

What made it even worse is that the TIDAL offer is only available to new TIDAL members, so although I only got to the card details screen, I still made an account, so in addition to having to spend ANOTHER 6.99 for the offer, I had to create another email just to redeem it. title: Ripped Me Off

review: Honestly the app is pretty good and is great at counting steps even without a fitness watch or anything and it adds up fairly quickly... I was expecting (from ads on instagram by other users) that there could be a direct payout to PayPal through this app. I was disappointed when I could not find one and the only offer for a PayPal payout was after 20,000 Sweatcoins. With this math, approximately 20 sc would be 1 usd which would also add up and it would be a much better app if there could be a direct payout. Although I understand the offers that sweatcoin needs to continuously run and be paid for it, there could be other ways of doing it. Like having multiple options for payout (including direct PayPal deposit) while possibly adding ads into the app which I wouldn‚Äôt mind, though I can‚Äôt speak for the rest of the population... overall a good app just not what I was expecting.
title: Not What I Was Expecting

review: Okay so I‚Äôve had this app for a while now, I wanna say over a year. I have around $480 in Sweatcoin- which is good I guess. But it‚Äôs been tracking my location this whole time. I‚Äôm assuming selling my data as well, because every time I swipe up to delete the app in the background it says ‚Äúoh Sweatcoin can‚Äôt run if you swipe it off the screen‚Äù.. takes a good amount of battery life. And for what? I‚Äôve not gotten a single ‚Äúprize‚Äù - if you could call them that.. it‚Äôs mainly just ‚Äú25% off‚Äù or ‚Äú50% off‚Äù things you have to BUY in the first place- and don‚Äôt forget the expensive shipping associated with every prize. There isn‚Äôt one ‚Äúprize‚Äù that is totally free. For an app that‚Äôs using your info to make money, you‚Äôd think they‚Äôd give out decent prizes but I guess not. I‚Äôll just stick to my reciept apps, at least they don‚Äôt have to be running every second of the day to make me a tiny amount of ‚Äúmoney‚Äù or coins. Smh
title: Tracks your location 24/7, for basically nothing.

review: This app seemed like a great idea when I downloaded it years ago. Now it seems like it was a huge waste of my time. I‚Äôve racked up around 3k coins and anytime I go to the shop all the prizes are sold out. Like I can check it, and then 10 mins later check it again and see new prizes and they are already sold out. It‚Äôs frustrating and has led me to just donate most of my coins‚Ä¶which now I‚Äôm wondering if those are even actually donated to the actual cause or not. There‚Äôs also some strange scam behind it because the auctions get up to massive coin amounts and having had this app for years and years and always have it running I‚Äôm wondering how all these winners of auctions are able to get so much coin. title: Was fun at first and now a waste

review: its cool that i can make money walking or whatever but i feel like there should be an option to cash out your sweatcoins on paypal or connect another bank account like it used to‚Ä¶like maybe after $100, people using the app should be able to use the money made for other things rather than just gifts that are sold out fast and stuff that people may not want and it takes long to make a certain amount of money, and plus the sweatcoin money would just sit there‚Ä¶i bought one thing on here and been using this for years and it was free so it dont even count‚Ä¶. title: 2/5 its okay but jot enough

developerResponse: {'id': 20999282, 'body': "Thank you for your review!\nWe're checking this out for you asap!", 'modified': '2021-02-11T13:33:48Z'}
review: The app ‚Äúincentivizes‚Äù you to walk by allowing you to redeem coins for merchandise. Except the merch is subpar and rarely free, you‚Äôll need to pay for inflated shipping. Any substantial and truly worthy reward redemption is easily 20K+ coins now with their auction system. It is extremely hard to earn that many coins unless you pay for their premium service AND walk an obscene amount of steps for MANY years. This is not an exaggeration. I‚Äôve had the app for 3 years now, paid for the premium service, and now the app refuses to count my steps for the last 3 days. I‚Äôve filed a complaint and want a full refund of the purchase. Will be deleting this app as soon as I get my money back. You‚Äôre better off using your phones standard health app to monitor steps. This app has very little benefit and offers minimal rewards - in my case, zero reward redemption given the impossibly high reward structure. Don‚Äôt waste your time on Sweatcoins.
title: No need for this app, just use your phones step counter

review:
The apps works as intended, looks great, and it‚Äôs a great way to give yourself a little incentive to move. I feel that the offers you can purchase with the sweatcoins are a little lacking though. Trials of trivial subscriptions, tv fitness programming (which baffles me, the idea of exercise is to get off the couch and quit staring at the tv), and the likes. Occasionally there is a cool gadget, but often it‚Äôs out of the price range unless you‚Äôve been using the apps for quite some time. It would be nice to see some more offer options, with items that have a little more use or value in them, especially for people who are relatively new to using the app. If there‚Äôs nothing you‚Äôre interested in, then it provides much less incentive to continue using the app and getting those steps in. 

tl:dr - Good app design and concept, but the offers could be executed better.
title: Great concept, but offers are lacking.

review: I‚Äôve built up tons of coins over the months because I walk about 5 miles a day at work. It really doesn‚Äôt matter how many coins I have because there is NEVER anything good in the shop. Hold on, let me check! Ok‚Ä¶ the best thing in there RIGHT NOW is ticket to an auction to win a curling iron??!!!! Hahahahaha you can‚Äôt make this up! Oh, and I see a Starbucks gift card but I can‚Äôt even buy it because it‚Äôs sold out. Any and everything halfway decent is always ‚Äúsold out‚Äù‚Ä¶.Otherwise it‚Äôs 50% off your first month‚Äôs subscription to some stupid company you‚Äôve never heard of. Also, the ads are deceptive!!!
