title: good app idea but some problems

review: I am a very busy person. Now with this app I was hoping to earn some cash in between things I need to do during the day. I think this app is a great idea, but it does not have the option to transfer the money I make walking to the bank account. The services they offer are nice, but I'm a harworking person and I need to spend my money on normal things like groceries for examples. If they can update the app to be able to connect to the bank account that would make this app so much better. I think more people would like this app more. Also, I think it would be helpful to be able to choose the option of "only while using the app" for the locations. It would be helpful so the phone does run out of battery. I'm on the go a lot so I need the phone to have battery. I hope the company who created this app can take these concerns into thought, because I would really like to use this app in the future.
title: Needs Improvement

review: To buy anything worth while, you‚Äôd have to max out your steps for half a decade. Even if you somehow managed to wait that long, you‚Äôd never be able to buy anything because every product worth purchasing is consistently sold out. I speculate that items are purposely listed as ‚Äúsold out‚Äù so that even if you had enough coins, you wouldn‚Äôt be able to buy it. The only other items available for purchase are a bunch of coupons for products no one has ever heard of. I assume this is how they make their money, which is why THESE items are always available for purchase. Very scummy app.
title: Don‚Äôt bother with this app

review: It only does this not fully and accurately account steps (only ‚Äúcalculates‚Äù about 1/3 of steps actually registered by my phone because that‚Äôs how their ‚Äúalgorithm‚Äù works it out...?) but you do not get money at all unless you manage to rack up literally $20,000 sweatcoin dollars to cash out for $1,000 on paypal IF that reward option is available. If it‚Äôs not you have plenty of other rewards to chose from as long as you‚Äôre a new user and agree to subscribing to whatever that reward service is - and the redemption process is about as convoluted as it gets. I‚Äôve tried several and still haven‚Äôt managed to redeem it correctly. Oh and to ‚Äòcount more steps‚Äô you have to become a paying subscriber to this app. Ya you might snag a good deal here and there (provided you remember to cancel whatever subscription they‚Äôre force feeding you) but otherwise it‚Äôs just a lame scam and not even an amusing one to participate in.
title: Doesn‚Äôt give you anything

review:
I've been using Sweatcoin for a few months and I walk a lot for my job, so I thought it would be worth it to keep the app for some extra "money" but I'm about to uninstall it because there are never any rewards I like. Most of the rewards are free trials for businesses that already do free trials. Besides those, you have "marathon offers" that'll take YEARS to get or invite offers. Right now they have an invite offer for $20 for PayPal for inviting 20 friends, but why can't I use my Sweatcoins to buy the $20 instead? Instead I'm stuck with offers like a free trial or discount for subscription services that already offer those without Sweatcoins. So, unless there's a reward that I feel is actually worth something that shows up in the next couple days, I'm deleting the app. 

(I'm only giving it 2 starts because I think the concept is cool, so that's worth 1 star)
title: No good rewards

review: I love the idea of this app! The downside is it‚Äôs really hard to get ‚Äòoutside steps‚Äô. I understand they don‚Äôt want people cheating but I walked 15,000 steps and sweat coin only counted 2,000 even though I was outside !!! The small prizes are nice little perks but the larger prizes are almost impossible if you don‚Äôt have a ton of friends it could literally take years to get. I hope they partner with apple and actually track the steps your phone already records then maybe their team can manually back track to help make sure there is no cheating. Hopefully one day it will count inside steps. It would also be nice if there sweat coins could turn into real cash one day. Other than that it‚Äôs a great motivator to get outside and start moving !!
title: Great Idea needs few improvements

review:
The indoor steps not counting, I can get to an extent but when I get 10k outside and it even shows I‚Äôve got 10k in steps on the app but only going to give me 2k worth of the pay out, this app is bogus! Customer service doesn‚Äôt reply because they know what they are doing and that‚Äôs ripping people off on a scam. Sure you get some money good for only what they have in their store, it‚Äôs not like it‚Äôs paying you actual money less you get 20k in sweat coin cash, which btw with the way they rip people off on their steps, will take you at least 20 months to get if you‚Äôre lucky!!! 
For the last 3 days the system registered 10k+ I‚Äôm steps but I was lucky to see MAYBE a 4K worth of steps pay out. If you don‚Äôt mind being cheated and it‚Äôs just for fun n to see what you can do than the apps for you, if you don‚Äôt like being cheated scammed and lied too and ignored than I‚Äôd go else where
title: Mediocre at best

developerResponse: {'id': 34843578, 'body': 'Hi. We really appreciate the feedback. Unfortunately, we have limited stock. We are working hard to partner with other companies who value your steps as much as we do, but we hope you understand this can be tricky! However, we are adding new offers all the time, so keep an eye out!', 'modified': '2023-02-13T17:29:20Z'}
review:
Unless you just want another app that tells you how many steps you‚Äôve taken, don‚Äôt download Sweatcoin. It tracks steps fairly okay and does give you currency. But the rewards you can buy are automatically marked out of stock as soon as they are added. The market refreshes early in the morning and when it does they are already out of stock. They only rewards that aren‚Äôt out of stock are the pointless ones like free trials. It‚Äôs very clear that the only rewards you can actually buy are just the sponsored free trials that give Sweatcoin money. 

There‚Äôs also a premium subscription which just makes no sense. And I‚Äôm grateful you can see premium only items in the store because guess what? They are also sold out upon being added. This app does not deserve to be on the App Store as it‚Äôs a straight up scam. 

TL:DR: The currency is all a lie so don‚Äôt download.
title: Straight up scam! Do not download!

review: I really like this app, it took me less than an hour to figure out, and you can really get stuff. My only issues are that you have to pay for shipping with real money. There should be an option to pay with sweatcoin. Easy to understand, Beautiful UI, fun competitions, and you can even send sweatcoin to friends. I would recommend, I just hope the development team sees this and considers adding my ideas. title: My opinion

review:
$1 is = 20 sweatcoins and 1000 steps roughly = 1 sweatcoin. you can only make up to 5 sweatcoins a day. So in 4 days you have to take over 5000 steps each day to get 1 dollar.
That‚Äôs 20,000 steps for $1 and guess what, you can‚Äôt trade in your sweatcoins for just $1 or even $20, they have to be traded in in numbers of (typically around) thousands, the only way to cash out for real money is if you spend 20,000 sweatcoins (200,000 steps total) for $1000 wich with your 5 sweat coin a day limit would take you at least 4,000 days or about 11 years. That‚Äôs 11 years of your life getting over 5000 steps a day for only $1,000 and it‚Äôs not even cash or anything, something like PayPal money or a airline voucher. 
So before you start this, realize you can only get a quarter a day and can only cash out after you get at least a few thousand sweatcoins. 
Hope this changes your mind on things.
title: Not very worth

review: Sweatcoin is a pretty good app. Every 1,000 steps give you a Sweatcoin, which can be redeemed in the shop, although the only good offers are the daily ones, which sell out very quickly. There is a daily boost, which doubles the Sweatcoins you earn for 20 minutes. I use this feature almost daily, and it worked fine until about four days ago. I started my daily boost, and when it was nearly over, I checked my steps. About 1,200. Once it was over, I reopened the app and it began processing the daily boost. After a little while, it finished. 0.33 sweatcoins. It should have been about 2.4. I thought it was just a glitch, but it happened the day after. Then it happened again, and again, and again today, March 21, 2023. PLEASE, FIX THIS and I will change the review to five stars.
title: It was fine until now.

review: I‚Äôve been using this app for 5 years simply letting it work in the background of my phone and have made 2,000 Sweatcoins. Years ago you were able to invite a friend and get 5$ on PayPal, I admit this did work but for some reason the app has slowly turned into a scam. I‚Äôve realized the gift cards go out of stock very fast, so I experimented to see. I started my free trial of premium to see if I would have more offers and I stayed on the app all morning refreshing to see if new gift cards would show up. Around 7:50 am the marketplace updated and the gift cards were immediately out of stock. Not saying this doesn‚Äôt make sense due to the amount of people who probably use the app, but I‚Äôve also tried to purchase a gift card and clearly it doesn‚Äôt work since I have not received my money yet. I‚Äôve been here awhile and I still say the app doesn‚Äôt work.

title: S&H Bank info

review:
I‚Äôve been a member for almost 4 years, with approximately 8 million steps converted in total. I‚Äôve also had the premium version for quite a while. However, even as a PREMIUM user, all offers are ‚ÄúOUT OF STOCK‚Äù. HOW? I check the app daily, and continue to accrue huge amounts of basically worthless credit on this app. I have NEVER been able to redeem an offer, because as soon as I try, it‚Äôs ‚Äúout of stock‚Äù. Trust me, this app is absolutely NOT worth a premium subscription if at all. I‚Äôve only been able to redeem my steps for a crappy subscription discount (don‚Äôt even get me started)

Anyways, don‚Äôt waste your time or money on this. What I thought could be a great motivator ended up becoming a huge distraction and frustration. My message is: Walk for YOU. Walk for YOUR HEALTH. It‚Äôs worth walking for your own well-being, not for some $10 gift card that will never happen. 

This is just an app designed to convert steps (and good intentions) into:

1.) a crappy subscription that‚Äôs nearly impossible to cancel, or

2.) to bait you into the app‚Äôs subscription, where you think you‚Äôll be able to redeem your ‚Äúcoins‚Äù into something eventually‚Ä¶ but really you‚Äôll just accrue them for years like myself- because everything is always ‚Äúout of stock‚Äù üôÉ
title: ‚ÄúOUT OF STOCK‚Äù.

review: first off, i just have to say, this is honestly a really good app, but there are a few problems. first, i understand why indoor steps aren‚Äôt counted but it‚Äôs also pretty annoying because i go to a pretty large high school and achieve 10,000+ steps just by walking to classes alone. i understand that people could easily manipulate the system by shaking their phones or whatever, but it still would be nice to track indoor steps to a certain extent. another problem that i‚Äôm sure developers are working on is the compatibility of newer smart watches like the apple watch series 4 which i have. my watch tracks all of my steps and workouts and since i don‚Äôt always have my phone on me, often times it doesn‚Äôt recognize those steps and workouts. another thing that i‚Äôve noticed is that if you‚Äôre working out, you have to go to the sweatcoin app on the watch for it to actually count. these are just a few little problems/concerns i‚Äôve noticed but otherwise, this is honestly a great app and is supporting a good cause. i love the fact that it promotes exercise and a general healthy lifestyle.

review:
Not only does this app encourage an enormous amount of people to actually engage themselves with our natural world, it also intertwines with our natural world the technological world. 

In my opinion, as the technological world ever increases and evolves our human capabilities, far to often do people forget about their role regarding the natural world. This app brings encourages individuals to explore, once again, the natural world that surrounds us. 

It allows me to adventure through the structure of this app, while most likely bringing me to furthur my involvement in what I have available around me; such as, going hiking on local trails I realized I haven't been on in years, walks with the dog to once-believed familiar locations that I forgot how beautiful they are to experience, and all while giving me the feeling of connectivity to an app that rewards every beautiful journy. 

I wish I found this app much earlier than I did, but I am glad I found it in the first place for it reminded me of all the marvelous places I can re-explore and have yet to explore. Thank you. üßóüèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüöµüèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüèûüì±üåçüåèüåé

title: Amazing with only one fault

review:
My health requires me to move and walking is my best way to address those issues. I like this app because it is not pressing me to do things I cannot. It measures how much I walk, and notices steps inside from those walked outside, and then rewards me with various incentives.
It has given me an alternative to the usual training/exercise app and gets me to try to do better than my previous level of steps at my own pace in my own time. Some days are better than others but I can always show progress. 
Oh... you can buy stuff with the sweat coins you earn. They are pushing it to a younger demographic , but that‚Äôs ok. They vary the rewards and something is sure to appeal.

Walk On!
title: Walking Cred

review: Sweatcoin, not too bad for a free app. Helps you get steps in with the promise of a reward. Customer service helped me when my steps stopped converting to Sweatcoins. But there are bot accounts on here, they always take the gift cards, and if you bid on an item I would recommend waiting until the last second as the bot accounts always places the highest bid. One of the ways you know that an account is a bot, is when you look at their profile and they have absolutely no sweat coins, and no steps history at all. I ran across one this morning placing the highest bid on a Scrabble board. In the end, the free premium trial gives you a good head start because it lets you get 30-31k steps in but I wouldn‚Äôt recommend spending any real money on this app.

{'id': 15078452, 'body': "Thank you for your review!
Sorry for any conversion issues you've run into... let's try and get things working again!
Firstly, please go to the AppStore and make sure there isn't an update available for Sweatcoin (we're releasing new versions often with new fixes all the time!).
Next, please try going to your device settings - general - background app refresh - scroll to Sweatcoin app and ensure it‚Äôs turned ON. Even if it's on, please toggle the switch off and on again, as this sometimes does the trick!
If this doesn't work, please make sure your device isn't on ‚ÄúLow Power Mode‚Äù as it could be interfering with things. To check, please go to your iPhone settings - ‚ÄúBattery‚Äù - ‚ÄúLow Power Mode‚Äù - See whether toggle is ON or OFF. It‚Äôs okay to have Low Power Mode on, but if so, please ensure you open Sweatcoin at least once every 12 hours!
If this doesn‚Äôt work, could it be that you have changed your time & date settings recently? This can interfere with our algorithm, so please make sure to set it to automatic and then reinstall our app :)

review: So i did the math for sweatcoin. And how long it should take you to get the 20,000 swc prizes and yea it takes up to 5 years to get those assuming you‚Äôre using the ‚Äúbreaker‚Äù subscription. (Btw idk why you would implement a subscription for us to pay with our steps monthly it holds us back.) title: TAKES 5 YEARS TO BUY THE GOOD STUFF

review:
If you don‚Äôt have a separate fitness tracker, then perhaps this app could be of value to you, extra motivation to get outside. Otherwise, skip this app and just rely on your Fitbit, etc...

Any of the rewards worth shooting for would require 2 years or more of 20k verified steps per day, if they are even still available once you amass the coins.  Most ‚Äúrewards‚Äù are like 5 coins for a one month trial of some app, and you can get a free one month trial anywhere. 

 A cool new feature is the charity donation option, but at 8 million coins to unlock a $3k donation, this values sweat coins at about 27 coins to the penny. Not really worth the effort.

The big issue with the app is the fickleness of the step algorithm.  Today I walked 3 miles around our neighborhood, but the app decided only 44 of my 6000 steps were valid.  The indoor tracking is a nice idea, but you are relying on your iPhone step counter, which misses most indoor steps anyway.  Yesterday, my Fitbit recorded 5k steps around the office, but iPhone only recognized 1k, and sweat coin only verified about 300.

Nice idea , but poor execution.  I suspect the issue is that the business mode does not generate enough revenue to fund real rewards or valuable charity donations.
title: Poor step algorithm - few rewards worth the effort

review: I uninstalled Sweatcoin a year ago because of battery drain but recently gave it another go. Things haven‚Äôt improved - even on battery saver mode the app is using a huge amount of power (my iPhone lost 40% battery today on a one-hour walk just sitting in my pocket). I like the option of donating your Sweatcoins to show support for a charity cause but read the small print - they are donating relatively small amounts of money compared with the impression you get from seeing millions of Sweatcoins donated. Some of the cheaper rewards seems to be free trials of subscription services. The only decent reward I could see was an iPhone XS for 19,999 coins. My app only registers around 5,000 steps a day (my Fitbit registers 12,000...), so that iPhone is 11 years away. Not a super offer in exchange for all your location data for the next decade...
title: Battery drainer, poor rewards

review: Genuine coupons from great places! Just got a bark box for $16 dollars when it would‚Äôve been $40. Sweatcoin gives you their currency of ‚Äúcash‚Äù that you earn from walking and you can buy coupons with them and other products. I don‚Äôt excessively walk or workout and I‚Äôm at $299 sweatcoin dollars. I would def give it a shot! You earn pints for referring friends and even just checking in every day. I was tired of apps that ‚Äúsaid‚Äù they gave you stuff for doing things and it took forever to add up or didn‚Äôt at all. Sweatcoin is the real deal! Love it and as long as you keep the app open in the background, it‚Äôs tracking your steps. It‚Äôs a thoughtless process! 10/10
title: Genuine üåü

review: So this app says what‚Äôs it does...... kind of. You do get ‚Äúsweat coins‚Äù but they don‚Äôt allow indoor steps to be counted (total BS, like what if I want to run on a treadmill?) and the conversion rate is not 1 step to 1 coin. I‚Äôve gotten like two free trials of subscriptions but not much else. I‚Äôve had the app for like 6 months and only saved up like 200 coins. They only offer things for limited times so unless you run marathons like every day, by the time you save up for a certain deal it‚Äôs been ‚Äúsold out.‚Äù Also a lot of their deals overlap with existing deals. Like for 50 sweatcoins you can get the first month free of some online subscription....... but that subscription already offers other first month free deals. It‚Äôs a pretty dumb app honestly. title: Kind of works, very shady

review: I‚Äôve been using this app for about 2 days and I love it. I get paid to walk! I‚Äôm 13 and babysitting is about the only thing I can do to get money. But with Sweat coin I can get money from literally walking it‚Äôs so easy. School is out soon and I‚Äôm so excited to just go outside and run getting paid the whole time. title: To be honest it‚Äôs disappointing

review: It certainly has been counting my time walking outside which is good. However it has some very annoying quirks.  The main one being the app‚Äôs weird anger at being ‚Äúforce quit‚Äù.  It doesn‚Äôt make sense why to me.  It has location tracking on all the time anyway so it should not be an issue to close to app.  The app needs to chill.  It also seems to get pointlessly angry if I just look at how many sweatcoing I got, leave the app WITHOUT force closing it and come back sometime later that day after it closing on its own because I used apps or some time has passed. For inexplicable reasons the app docks you sweat coins for this behavior and it‚Äôs just obnoxious to the point of me dropping a star.

You get a sweatcoin every 1000 steps and you can earn up to 5 sweatcoins each day for free, but of course you can upgrade about 4 times to earn more sweatcoins per day. title: Good app but false advertising

review:
That app claims not to use much battery life... well, it has to access your gps, so you have to ‚Äúalways‚Äù have your location on, therefore, it uses much more battery then an app should have too. Today, around 6:15pm, Indiana time, I turned my gps on and I had a fully charged (100%) battery... it is now 7:40pm and my battery life is at 70%... smdh... come on are you freaking kidding me?!?!?!
I‚Äôm also disappointed in the fact you don‚Äôt actually ‚Äúget paid‚Äù. Yes, you get sweat coin, but you can only use it to purchase the things/items they have through the app/company. It‚Äôs nonsense that they can‚Äôt convert it to be put on a PayPal account/card, a bank account, or some other form of payment. I may delete this app, even though the initial incentive (money) got me to get out and be more active/healthy.
Such an utter disappointment!!!
title: Battery usage

review:
The only thing that I can think of that would make this better is that more can be done than just walking. I am a boxer and work up quite the sweat in the gym. The solution that I think would be best is to find a way to count indoor steps for you know people like nurses and other occupations that work on there feet all day indoors and find a way to use a heartbeat sensor to give coins to elevated heart rate that shows someone is working out either at home or in the gym.

Other than this, I love this app. I have gotten to try many cool products that I wouldn‚Äôt have tried otherwise such as Scribd because I never heard of it but got a 60 day trial. I now pay for that app. So Sweatcoin‚Äôs works for me and I love it. I will forever use it.
title: Great app

review: Pretty cool app and you can legitimately use the coins you earn just from walking around each day. The coolest feature though is being able to buy physical products with the coins. Unfortunately I have not once ever open the app and there be any available. They‚Äôre always out of stock I‚Äôve tried getting on at different times of the day. One time I even thought something was in stock and went through the purchase process only to have it fail. I wish they would expand their physical product offerings it seems like they only have a few each day. Either you have to be extremely lucky or perhaps they give priority to paying members in my opinion is pretty lame.
title: It‚Äôs cool to a point.

review:
There are a few things I‚Äôd have to say. First off people are busy and work a ton. Some even have indoor tracks at recreational facilities. Things like that. Count indoor steps!! It‚Äôs not like it‚Äôll do anything but boost customer satisfaction. Which brings me to another point. It takes years to earn anything of value unless you‚Äôre running cross country or jogging 15 miles a day (literally).

I understand the fresh company but make these values more accessible. No one will use your app for that long with no return. A good counter would as I said make the indoor steps count. Also have a straight money function. You took PayPal off except the 20,000 sweatcoin reward which is absolutely ridiculous. Lower your product coin prices or make better rewards. Fix these things and I think you‚Äôll have something everyone wants.
title: Too long to see results

review: I see a lot of people complaining about this app not counting all their steps or not getting currency fast enough. When I‚Äôm reality at the end of the day it‚Äôs still free money for just walking and living your normal day life whether it be exercising or just walking in general. If it takes a year or a day it‚Äôs still a great thing because it‚Äôs free and there are rewards for being an active healthy person. People need to stop being so entitled because they‚Äôre not getting what they want when they want for FREE. In closing I recommend this app to everyone I know because it‚Äôs an incredible idea that encourages people to get active and I will continue to use it.
title: GREAT APP

developerResponse: {'id': 23903600, 'body': "Thanks for your review!\nThis was a test feature that we're now reworking - thanks for testing with us!", 'modified': '2021-07-13T11:30:26Z'}
review:
I have been using Sweatcoin for over a year now. I came across this cool thing today on there. It said I could set a goal for how much I wanted to walk this year. It asked me to set how many steps I wanted to take for the whole year, based on what I did last year. It also told me how many steps per day that would be on average. It gave me the percentage of how much more or less my goal was compared to how many steps I took last year. I thought this was awesome. 

Until I tried to get back to it. Now I can‚Äôt find it. That‚Äôs the crappy part about Sweatcoin, it‚Äôs not very well organized. Things get lost on the app so easily. And it changes everyday. 

The concept is that you get Sweatcoins for how much steps you take everyday. With these sweatcoins, you‚Äôre able to choose to purchase different promotional items they have listed. These promotional items change everyday. Usually it‚Äôs like a necklace that you just pay shipping for plus 100 Sweatcoins. 

They also have bidding for higher priced items such as the Xbox Series X. These go for like 30,000 Sweatcoins I think. I only have a little over 1000 Sweatcoins and I‚Äôve been using the app for a year or two now.
title: Sweatcoin Goals

developerResponse:
{'id': 15595533, 'body': "Thank you for your valuable feedback and review here!
Sorry for any conversion issues you've run into... let's try and get things working again! 
Firstly, please go to the AppStore and make sure there isn't an update available for Sweatcoin (we're releasing new versions often with new fixes all the time!).
Next, please try going to your device settings > general > background app refresh > scroll to Sweatcoin app and ensure it‚Äôs turned ON. Even if it's on, please toggle the switch off and on again, as this sometimes does the trick!
If this doesn't work, please make sure your device isn't on ‚ÄúLow Power Mode‚Äù as it could be interfering with things. To check, please go to your iPhone settings > ‚ÄúBattery‚Äù > ‚ÄúLow Power Mode‚Äù > See whether toggle is ON or OFF. It‚Äôs okay to have Low Power Mode on, but if so, please ensure you open Sweatcoin at least once every 12 hours!
If this doesn‚Äôt work, could it be that you have changed your time & date settings recently? This can interfere with our algorithm, so please make sure to set it to automatic and then reinstall our app :)
", 'modified': '2020-05-27T09:23:15Z'}
review:
Don‚Äôt know what algorithm they use but it isn‚Äôt good. I walk outside for 13,000 steps and I will get maybe $8 in sweatcoin if I‚Äôm lucky. Also tried the 2x bonus for 20mins and got 2,300 steps, so I figured I would get around $4.60 in sweatcoins right? Nope, I got $.79 worth. I‚Äôve got the most recent update so that‚Äôs not the issue. I like using the app, but there are definitely issues that need to be tended to.

Update...

Just got done with a walk with the 2x bonus activated again and got another 2,250 steps, so if you double that, that would make 4,500 steps. And with a 90% conversion rate like they claim, that should be a $4.05 in sweatcoin. Did I get that? Nope! Not even close. I did get a whopping $1.07 in sweatcoin though, so it should rather be called the 1/2x bonus. The conversion of these steps is bad at best.

Don't force quit me!" Reminds me of the crazy stalker you see in movies as he pops up and bangs on your window. The couple of awesome rewards will take years to achieve and I'm guessing they hope no one will reach them before this app goes the way of the pager.
title: Great in theory

To call it a crypto currency is just fraud because you can‚Äôt convert any of it to dollars or spend it anywhere else than the in app shop. I‚Äôm keeping the app just for the sake of the possibilities, but if the app developers really want to improve it and make it the next big thing, it needs some major improvements and better offers. title: So many problems

I‚Äôve had this app for a month or 2 and I‚Äôve acquired a total of 60 coins, and I still haven‚Äôt bought anything. Because of this, I have earned a great amount of sweatcoins BUT I have yet to come across a likable item that wasn‚Äôt sold out by the time I saw it, or items that don‚Äôt require you to make a purchase of some sort, such as paying for shipping or a subscription service. This hasn‚Äôt deterred me from the app yet, but it might one day. Although shipping is never expensive, I don‚Äôt see why my hard earned sweatcoins are put towards a prize that I still have to spend money on.  I just see it as a cash grab but I‚Äôm not giving up yet!
title: Good, but not great

review: I have a new Apple Watch and got this app on the phone and the watch to count my steps. I take about 8,000 daily and maybe  6k are outdoors on trails. About half the time the watch picks up the steps,  but the other half it says it will load to their system and let me know when it is done... then nothing happens. My Apple Watch native app picks up all the steps no problem, but Sweatcoin says I had no steps at all... so something doesn‚Äôt work right with their app. I am using other apps that pay me sien money and I trust them more than this one and that is a shame. I would like to be able to use this one because I like what they are they are trying to do with cryptocurrency and blockchain. But, I am actually getting paid and credit for all of my outdoor and indoor steps with other apps.
title: Doesn‚Äôt count outside steps properly

review: I‚Äôve really liked this app and had it for a long time but lately every time I check out the prizes such as a gift card they are always sold out no matter when I check to see if new prizes are available. The most frustrating part is that only 20-30 people have gotten the prize so there needs to be a way where there are more to choose from or more that people can purchase. I usually check first thing in the morning and last thing at night and are ALWAYS sold out. I have the coins to be able to purchase them so what‚Äôs the point in having the app if you cant even get anything.
title: Good but frustrating

review: I got this app a while back and was on the shaker plan which allows you to register 10,000 steps into 10 sweat coins, everything was great at first and I was hitting the max cap almost daily because I walk around a lot for my job and I have a dog which I walk daily so I usually get a lot of steps, the app kept insisting that I upgrade to avoid losing steps. I figured why not, this I where the trouble began. It‚Äôs been almost a full month and I have yet to register more than 5,000 steps a day through their algorithm although my daily habits haven‚Äôt changed. I get around 15-20,000 steps in a day. I find it very odd and a bit cheated that this problem started once I upgraded my subscription, I always keep the app open and running as recommended to get the most out of my step count but so far nothin has helped
title: This app cheats you

review:
So everyone talks about how the app doesn‚Äôt count all your steps‚Ä¶ but what about paying with sweatcoins for free trials in other apps!? Like, if I want a free trial I can just download the app I want and do it, without wasting any sweatcoins. It‚Äôs not like they‚Äôre gonna give you extra time in the trial or anything. And everything in the shop is always, and I mean ALWAYS, out of stock. I‚Äôve been using the app for a few months and I‚Äôm still waiting for the day I‚Äôm gonna see anything available. 
Everything in the shop it‚Äôs just a joke. Pay for free trials‚Ä¶ things out of stock‚Ä¶ and the one that are available are just discounts for a big purchase.
I‚Äôm very disappointed.
And 20k sweatcoins to actually be able to get real money? How many years is that? You can walk a lot but they are not counting all your steps so you‚Äôll never get there.
title: Wow!

review: Not gonna lie, this is a really cool app, but good lord this thing is terrible at counting my steps. I was referred to the app by my friend, considering that I walk a lot, I might as well try it out. I‚Äôm in high school, and our campus is HUGE... so I have to walk around a LOT. So far, I‚Äôve walked (or so the app says) 3,299 steps. Can you guess how many approved steps? One hundred sixty fuggin two steps. 162 steps. Honestly, devs, if you have a problem of people shaking their phones getting free steps, why don‚Äôt you have some kind of location tracker? I play pok√©mon go, and they ACTUALLY count your steps. Amazing right?? So, suggestion, for more accurate steps, track the users location to see wether they‚Äôre moving or not, so you can more accurately count it. Because yeah, now I feel hecka cheated. Ty!
title: Uncounted steps :/

review: I‚Äôm kinda hoping I can convince some more people to get this app so here goes. There is nothing negative for me to talk about this app it‚Äôs all positive. title: Sweatcoins the best

review:
I am a construction worker and I work outside between 60 and 75 hours a week and on average the iPhone health app measures around 15k steps a day.  On average I walk about 40 miles a week at work alone.  I have no idea how accurate that measurement is but it seems about right. 

A lot of reviews are of people whining about how far they‚Äôd have to walk to get a certain item, try getting a real job LOL. For only having to walk, I‚Äôm not going to complain if I have to wait for a good deal or if it doesn‚Äôt track every single step. Free is free and my phone is in my pocket all day already so what the heck. 

Scrolling though the shop I see that I can trade 10 SWC for $10 off my electric bill. Right there, it‚Äôs worth it. People don‚Äôt tip us and it‚Äôs nice to see an app that will essentially do that, especially so because I‚Äôve suffered some truly terrifying injuries and haven‚Äôt recovered financially from the lost hours thus far. 

My kids are using it now as well and I‚Äôm not sure what they think they‚Äôre going to do with it but if it gets them outside and away from Minecraft I‚Äôm all for it lol
title: Use it at work

review:
Let me start off by saying I coach track, so I‚Äôm outside a huge part of my day, and I get close to 20,000 steps per day. Sweat Coin has yet to ‚Äúregister‚Äù more than 1000 for me in a day. Now granted, I‚Äôve only had it a week, but I have seen no difference day to day. The algorithm they have is faulty at best, and is a downright cheat at worst. Honestly, it seems like they are blame shifting by automatically saying that they won‚Äôt allow cheating, but consistently cheat their users out of thousands of steps every day. Tracking my data comes at a price, and it‚Äôs not very high: fairness. You have cool deals, and fun offers, but you make it impossible to achieve them. 

Overall, setup is clean and user friendly, but the operating system that calculates steps is anything but. I‚Äôll give it another week, but am not very hopeful.
title: Has promise, but fails to deliver

review:
Concept brilliant...walk and earn sweat coin and redeem for gift. Classic example of when something is too good to be true, it‚Äôs most likely isn‚Äôt.

Heard about this app from my brother in law and kept asking myself how do they earn money.  So tried it.

Free users can only earn 5 sweat coin a day max and their algorithm only track outside steps which is good and if you pay the maximum number of coins you earn increases. The lucrative gifts are prized at around 3600 swat coins and above so imagine how long it‚Äôll take for a free user to reach with 5 per day max limit. I was still ok with it. 

Then I started checking the easy offers that cost 5 sweat coin or similar less. Then I went to the actual companies to see if such offer exist in their website. SURPRISE!!! The offers are actually free in the company web site . For example one get an offer of free one month of Bean Box coffee by spending 5 sweatcoin and $3 for s/h. If you go to Bean Box coffee website they are giving one month free trial by paying $3 for s/h. 

And same for all such low priced offer in app.

This reveals how fraud they are and that‚Äôs their business model. They get ad money from these companies like bean bag coffee and offer something for free as something you need to earn for.

Real frauds
title: Fraudulent app... get few return if you pay

review: The app doesn‚Äôt count all of your steps towards all your goals. For example if you are unlocking a great deal it may say you only had 9000 steps except the sweat coin will have refreshed to reflect that you‚Äôve walked more than 12k which makes no sense. It doesn‚Äôt update properly. My Fitbit also says that I‚Äôve walked more than 15k most days. Sweat coin will shortchange me and say I only did maybe 10k. I‚Äôm not going to move into premium memberships unless that‚Äôs fixed because why am I going to give money to an app developer who can‚Äôt get the free version working correctly. Make it sync between with Fitbit and reflect my actual steps or just be another step counter and lose out. May even delete because of permissions to collect my data. Don‚Äôt need you making money off me if I can‚Äôt be treated with respect.
title: Good encouragement except

The items that are appealing on the sweatcoin shop can only be purchased through bidding. Unfortunately, the bidding items regularly go for what would work out to millions of steps. The ways to make extra sweatcoins are either through paying for faster sweatcoin accumulation or watching ads. There is no way you come out ahead using this app as the time you waste will be infinitely more valuable than anything the sweatcoins allow you to purchase.

review:
This app is genius. You literally will forget about it being there, like all your apps you don‚Äôt use often, and boom 5$ in sweatcoins! , then 10$, then 25$! 

I‚Äôve had it for almost two years and I started slow. I was skeptical because was it real? Little did I know how real it can be! I bought a couple things already like the PayPal invite for cash. I hooked it up and got my invites and clicked on the ‚Äúoffer‚Äù and read the instructions on how to get the money. Followed it and bam! My cash 10$ was in my PayPal account. 
I barely walk y‚Äôall. From my car to my house and back. Let‚Äôs not forget my weekly grocery store and if I walk daily enough my indoor steps count.  Maybe a few bachelorette parties may have helped but every step counts right? Who said drunk ones don‚Äôt!? Least I‚Äôm not driving. üòÑ Anyway...

 I‚Äôm now around $1,100 in sweatcoins  and growing with every day. 
Thank you sweatcoin for the continuous offers as I‚Äôm reaching my goal to hit some marathon offers next time. Greece would be dope.  Hope this review helps! üôÇ

title: Love it! INSPIRATIONAL!!

developerResponse: {'id': 16141435, 'body': "Thanks for your review!\nRegarding the marathon offers, we know for most it does take a while -- but please understand that our mission here at Sweatcoin is to make the world more active, so we want to make sure people are really working hard and gaining something when they reach that well deserved goal. Happy Sweatcoining and let us know if you need any additional information or assistance using the app! :)\n", 'modified': '2020-06-22T10:39:18Z'}
review:
The prizes are pretty much all things you can get for free or for the same cost they are offered without the need to build up sweat coins.  They will be charging these companies to advertise their products to you, then you have to spend time and money to get a free product and more than likely pay increases postage.

Until recently you could only max out on 20K steps per day, now you can do more if you pay a subscription.  So you are working (watching ads, using your battery life, ruining your phone and watch battery) and now paying them to try and earn free products.

The only decent prizes are 8000 sweatcoins upwards, if you don‚Äôt spin for prizes or do the boost that is 8,00,000 steps or for most people 4000 miles of walking.  That gets you a $200 camera.... 

The average person will take 3 years to walk 4000 miles.

In 3 years time, you‚Äôve spent a load of time, plus killed the batteries in however many phones / watches you have gone through, plus maybe paid the subscription to try and get you there sooner and guess what the only way to make this app profitable will be for them to up the cost of the good prizes further or devalue a sweat coin.

Oh and in meantime you‚Äôre also giving them all your data for free.

Don‚Äôt be a fool.
title: Fools gold.....

review:
For security concerns with my job and who is actually getting my location data, I don‚Äôt like that the app must always be using my GPS when I only use the app at certain times outdoors. 

Why give the option of ‚Äúwhile using‚Äù if that is a lie? Also, a rise in scammers monetizing the app for personal gain by sending small amounts of coin to beg for more coins in return because they claim they ‚Äú...don‚Äôt know how the game works and they are new.‚Äù Except I can see their activity and they are converting more coin in a day than I do in a week. 

The perks aren‚Äôt plentiful or great. I donated all of my coins to the charities since the coins can‚Äôt buy anything useful anyway. If you do the math on what it takes to realistically hit goals for cash or phones or some of the better perks, it would take years to hit and more than a normal amount of miles even if you work a job where you avg 10 miles a day. Given that steps are dropped, this is beyond frustrating and a futile effort. Either perks run out or they are not fully funded or good. 

Deleting the app. It has been a year and I see no real benefit to let it kill my battery by running my gps constantly. I sent a message about this to the Dev before. Now it isn‚Äôt worth the space it takes up.
title: Many concerns with this app

review: This is a great app. I got my Mous case for 50% off because of this app. But I believe this app should connect to our health app so it can count steps properly. I am a marathon runner. So I cap at 20 sweatcoins a few times a week. I understand if this app is trying to make money by only giving discounts, but I have tried promoting this app around my area because it is legit. And unfortunately, I got some backlash because it doesn't give anything for 100% free. Please find a way to let us get our free purchases because our hard work does not completely pay off like you guys say it does.
title: Great app but...

review: The step conversion is off quite a bit and it‚Äôs extremely discouraging when you do a ton of steps through out the day and it seems like less than half the steps are even being accounted for. They say the step algorithm counts about 65% of users steps....I call BS. When I spend about 80% of my day outside doing vigorous yard work I would fully expect most of my steps (90-95%) to be accounted for. I can understand maybe some of the indoor steps not being counted because of GPS signal and all of that but if I‚Äôm outdoors walking all of my steps should be accounted for. I upgraded to the shaker because at first I was going over my limit but I started noticing more often my steps were not being counted. I will DEFINITELY be downgrading or even deleting this app if this algorithm crap does not improve!
title: Good but could be a lot better!

Unfortunately I feel like I have come too far to turn back and delete the app because I have built up a lot of points over two years. But the shenanigans are starting to really tick me off! If you want us to watch six ads then just say it, don‚Äôt trick people into watching up to 6 ads for bonus points. I have written several times with no response. It‚Äôs really not that hard to be fair with people!
title: Tired of the tricks

developerResponse: {'id': 15570899, 'body': "Hey -- thank you for your review here.\nWe appreciate that these short term fixes of checking the background app refresh settings isn't ideal. We're working hard with Apple to find a fix and hope this won't be the case moving forward! :)", 'modified': '2020-05-26T11:09:35Z'}
review:
Here‚Äôs what keeps this app from being great: 1. You have to open the app once every 12 hours
2. You can‚Äôt have background app refresh disabled 
3. You can‚Äôt be on low battery mode
4. You can‚Äôt force stop the app

If you do any of those things, your steps won‚Äôt convert. If you don‚Äôt update your app in time; same thing. I walk over four miles a day and my steps are rarely counted. The rewards on this app are not worth the hassle. I don‚Äôt want to be thinking about this app every day. I don‚Äôt want to drain my battery for this app. The prizes are mediocre at best, but in all honesty, in the years I‚Äôve had this app, I have yet to see something I would care enough to get. 

I don‚Äôt appreciate having to change settings on my phone that make my battery drain faster - even if they claim this app doesn‚Äôt drain your battery, the settings you‚Äôre forced to use certainly will. When you‚Äôre on a long walk/run, not feasible. It‚Äôs just one of those apps that SHOULD be super low maintenance, yet every time I check it, I realize my steps haven‚Äôt converted in weeks, even though I never stopped the app from running in the background. It‚Äôs just annoying. Thank god it‚Äôs free.

title: Hard work

title: Feels pointless

title: Pretty good

review:
The Sweat Coin app seems very motivational...except it is sadly useless for those of us who use our walking time to set aside our phones. If only your app could recognize steps recorded by FitBit!  I know the app accommodates Apple Watch users so perhaps in the future it will be able to be utilized by those of us who use FitBits. It also hassles you when you turn off the app - even though it can‚Äôt count any steps inside.  I understand the whole GPS thing; but if it truly has no use inside, then there‚Äôs no reason for the app to need to be on all the time and have access all the time.  And it‚Äôs not for our convenience or so we don‚Äôt forget: if that were the case, then the app would still work when it could only have access when it‚Äôs on. I do almost all of my walking/running at the gym in the afternoon. I really didn‚Äôt think this would be an issue as the location is always on and assumed the app would be able to place me at the gym, however, they really mean it when they say walk outside.

I think the only way this app could even begin to become useable is if the developers accepted that sweatcoin is just another trashy ‚Äòwatch ads and complete tasks to get discounts and one or two bucks now and then‚Äô app. If you expect anything else, sweatcoin isn‚Äôt for you.

title: Nothing in this world is free or given to you

review: Don't be fooled by the flashy interface. This app is ok for counting steps, despite its limitations in converting steps to sweat coins. That's not a problem though as the products offered in the marketplace are of questionable quality and you pay a premium in shipping for the physical products. I suggest researching reviews from outside the app...if you can even find them as many are so obscure. The daily bonus is an absolute joke (not the funny kind). I had a representative come clean with me after claiming that the spins were not rigged. I "won" more than 4sc (out of a possible 3000 in 3 daily spins) about once a month. In all, use sweat coin for counting steps, but if you can't find motivation to walk from within, this is not the place. I won't be back.
title: Don't be fooled

review:

If you wanted to use this app to make your life easier in the for of many subtle money collection apps then I wouldn‚Äôt use this one. This app is for joggers and racers who move far distances daily and also have the free time to check the gift card drops I guess. Because I walk all day for my job.

I‚Äôve gotten some good things from this app like a great water bottle and some shoelaces. But all of the good ‚Äúpay with sweatcoins‚Äù products sell out so quickly now that I‚Äôm beginning to wonder why I even bother using the app anymore.

review:
I found this cool app that pays you to walk basically and you can also share with friends and family and get a reward. So I ran for a mile and a half and earned about 3 dollars. Being so excited I shared it with my friends and family. I shared it with about 15 people. That‚Äôs not including the ones they perhaps shared because I know they did. And now they want to block me? Apparently that‚Äôs considered inappropriate. This is the email I received. 

Hi Daniel,

Your account was flagged by our algorithms for suspicious or inappropriate activity.

You may create a new account using another phone number and begin to use Sweatcoin again following the agreed T&C‚Äôs.

Please take care to ensure this doesn‚Äôt happen again.

So now basically I can‚Äôt get back in and have to change my number to create a new account and lose the money that I earned. It‚Äôs a shame I was really looking forward to using this app it actually encouraged me to run today. But I feel they used me and the people I know and blocked me from receiving any benefits. 

So if you get the app do not share it because they are likely to block you.  

I only gave it one star because I have to. Unless they make it right.

developerResponse: {'id': 39386127, 'body': 'We appreciate your feedback here and will pass this along to our wider team for future improvements!\r\n\r\n', 'modified': '2023-10-08T11:20:12Z'}
review:
I‚Äôve been a user for 5 or so years and here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned:

- For a free app, it‚Äôs not bad. You convert walking into the in-app currency of Sweatcoin. 

- These coins can be used to purchase items in the market place. However, most of the offers or things to buy are just normal trial packs, bundles, or plain ads companies already sell. You‚Äôre not getting anything new. I‚Äôve gotten these ‚Äúoffers‚Äù before. Usually these are the same as trial offers/packs but cost Sweatcoins rather than be free. The marketplace doesn‚Äôt really feel like a marketplace. It feels like the Times Square of Sweatcoin, tons to look at, but it‚Äôs all ads. Kind of annoying. 

- There are some big ticket items, but most of these are raffles, or cost 20,000 sweatcoins. For reference, .95 Sweatcoin equates to 1,000 steps (with a cap of 5,000 a day unless you pay for premium membership, in which you have a higher cap and earn more per 1,000 steps)

Overall, it‚Äôs a fine app. Nothing special with a lower-than-mediocre marketplace that‚Äôs basically just full of ads.

title: Disappointed

review:
I used to love this app, and I talked my entire family into using it. However, since the latest update the app is broken, and personally unusable. 

Essentially the app keeps track of your steps, converts them into ‚ÄúStepcoins‚Äù which you can use to purchase items. Before the latest update these steps were tracked/verified via GPS. This was wonderful for outdoor walking, as well as any distance greater than a hundred feet or so, and I regularly made 10,000 or more steps. This was only a few thousand of from my Fitbit count, so I was happy. 

I purchased the subscription that allows me to earn more coins per day, and I was racking them up quickly. Then the new update hit, and I have been losing points each month as the app refuses to count my steps anymore. I  have tried reinstalling, fixing permissions, and leaving the app open 24/7. I am now making around 2,000 steps maximum, despite my Fitbit still recording 10k+. 

I don‚Äôt understand the need to change systems, and it has ruined the experience for me. I won‚Äôt be using the app until this is fixed, and I will continue to recommend people use other apps that keep better track of their steps.

title: Getting angry with it

I earned 8 sweatcoins in two days (seems low, but this will let you get quite a few offers). Be warned that not all steps will be counted. However, only a small portion. One time I had 1,400 steps and it verified about 1,300 steps. So it‚Äôs reasonably fair. If you try to cheat the system, then of course over half your steps won‚Äôt be verified. The only true con is that the offers don‚Äôt change as quickly as I had hoped. New offers should be added every other day and really old ones replaced.
title: Great idea! Offers are limited sadly

review: Accidentally changed my day when I got my new phone a day early and quickly changed it back when I had the app running and now it‚Äôs refuses to take any of my sweatcoins.. IT WILL COUNT them but won‚Äôt convert them. I believe it‚Äôs because of the day change. It hasn‚Äôt fixed itself. I‚Äôve deleted and redownloadedcthe app restarted my phone and nothing. I currently have 1000 sweatcoins just sitting there to waste with no way of getting more. I have tried to contact the company but to no avail. If I could get some support on my problem I would be thankful. I am a current user of sweatcoin and I would love if I could generate more. Thank you
title: Won‚Äôt generate my steps PEASE HELP

review:
So I have two basic complaints 
1. It doesn‚Äôt truly count steps wish there was a way to connect to Fitbit or Apple Watch - so because it‚Äôs get somewhere between 1/3 to 2/3 of the steps and for people like me who don‚Äôt always carry their phone with them can account for the steps they‚Äôve taken. 
2. The stupid message that pops up when you accidentally close the app. Okay I get it. It happens. But there is absolutely no reason for it to be there. But if you don‚Äôt click on the accept button then it won‚Äôt count steps. Lost an entire day of steps due to that. 
I would love to give it a higher score but those two things are reasons enough to keep it at a 3 for me.
title: Want it to just be better

review:
It‚Äôs not that the daily rewards are hard to get, but the fact that they almost never work. That‚Äôs a free 7 Sweatcoin you miss out on every three days because the ads refuse to load. Over the course of the month you could lose out on 70 Sweatcoin! 

Other than that, the app works like it says it does, using gps to determine location and providing Sweatcoin for steps taken outside. The app has to be running in the background in order to count steps and then your steps are run through an algorithm to determine payout. One of the best features is the ability to upgrade by paying in Sweatcoin. 

Overall opinion: good app, fix the daily reward issue, easy to use.
title: Good App: Daily Rewards, Not So Great

review: This app has a pretty solid concept and it works pretty great. The only annoying things are that sometimes the steps don‚Äôt register, which is normal and the company is trying to fix. The thing that I don‚Äôt like at all is that there is a sweat coin cap on how much you can earn per day. If you were to run a marathon you couldn‚Äôt register all those steps unless you buy a monthly subscription (which I think should be a one time purchase) which ups the amount of sweat coins you can get in a day which still only goes up to 25. You should be able to gain an unlimited amount per day. Some of the more expensive prizes need a lot of sweat coins which you‚Äôll almost never get with the cap
title: Pretty good

review: Not sure how accurate the steps are - but what I can tell you is that there is NO MONEY involved.  You cannot cash out your earnings - all you can do is ‚Äòpurchase‚Äô special offers (for which you still have to pay actual money) and while you might (and I haven‚Äôt seen anyone of the available in the several months I‚Äôve used the app) be able to actually purchase from the looks of it you actually have to pay to be able to get them as well. Only reason I continue to use it is because it gives me an idea of how many steps I take - so long as my phone is on me. If you think you‚Äôre actually gonna get cash for walking - think again it ai t happening here.
title: Lies basically

review: I like it. Very promising. I walk a lot so why not. However today it got a notification that the app/phone was shut down and lost steps. My phone is NEVER shut down. So that‚Äôs interesting... the app is ALWAYS open and active  and still tells me it was shutdown. Why can‚Äôt it run in the background like Fitbit?!? Why can‚Äôt it record indoor steps...like...Fitbit?!? A step is a step. If your using the phone gps data it‚Äôs a no brainer. This is the only app Out of hundreds that I have used that requires it to be open all of the time. If you say you can use the iPhone health app steps then you should not need to be open. You should be able to do like fitbit and pull it in from the Apple Watch or the health app (when it is opened) on the phone and update your steps because they both have an accurate count of what is going on.
title: Hmm

review: I really like the new update. From changing the app icon to updating the user interface, this app just keeps getting better. I am really wanting to try the new method of counting steps, and hope they have more to offer and are more consistent than the older way. I have personally had this app for about 2 years now and the step counter always seemed a little off, so I will be looking forward to that new feature. I also like the nice color changes and I hope we get bigger and better updates in the future. Keep up with the hard work!
title: My Review

review:
Stayed up to do a little experiment. Waited until the app put up a new item for purchase with coins to see how long they stay up for.

Sure enough, not even a good few minutes past stock reset and the new item is already gone.

Other issues include:
-Items in stock suddenly being out of stock when you go to buy them, even after several app reloads and the button STILL SAYING BUY NOW.
-EVEN THE PREMIUM REWARDS ARE GONE SECONDS AFTER GOING UP. AT TWILIGHT HOURS. NEAR SUNRISE, FOR GOD‚ÄôS SAKE.
-Constant crashes every other day or so. For no reason. I‚Äôm not even doing anything stupid; just reloading the shop.
-Inaccurate step counting. To put this bluntly, it can tell when you‚Äôre in bed doing things. This is not a joke. Seriously. At home, in bed, in one spot, and this godforsaken application decides we‚Äôre running a marathon. HOW. WHY.
-overall not a very motivational fitness app if I have to deal with both getting fit and trying to redeem ANYTHING on this mess

I mean, I‚Äôm sure someone‚Äôs managed to actually redeem something but the way I see it there‚Äôs no way to get anything on here, even staying up late for the new reward to go on sale. üòï
title: I wasted too much time.

review: The app was a great way to working out and earn money they you could cash out to PayPal when it first came out and I really enjoy it because it gave me a reason to work out and also have a little fun but when they update the app the only way you cash out to your PayPal is if you invite people to the app and when you hit that number of people you had to invite then you can cash. That update made me dislike the app and I wish y‚Äôall can just let people withdraw their money in to PayPal like you used to do but it is still a great app but the app is not me more because I want to spend my money on what ever I want in the app or outside the app.
title: It‚Äôs a good app

review: Started this app and the first day it went well. Second day I opened the app on my Apple Watch. The app claimed that I could begin a workout without my watch in sight. I got on the treadmill and walked/ran for 1 mile, approximately 2,000 steps). It said that it would let me know when my steps converted. NEVER DID!! I tried deleting the app multiple times to try and see if that helped, and I know I have the most updated version because the initial download was after the latest upgrade. As a nurse I walk constantly throughout the day, but I do not carry my phone with me into patient rooms. To claim you work with the Apple Watch and then don‚Äôt is upsetting to say the least. FIX THIS!! Also took a video of the app on the watch but can‚Äôt load it or a still picture on the review.
title: Doesn‚Äôt work with Apple Watch like it claims!!

review: Everyone not giving 5 stars is complaining about the products costing too many sweatcoins or whining about paying shipping... This app is amazing if you‚Äôre willing to be patient and get those steps! Its silly that these people can‚Äôt appreciate everything that comes with this app. The whole premise is to get people active and the fact that you actually able to earn rewards is incredible.

review:

It worked kinda Ok for this period with better days when it converted all my 10 coins (I walk a lot but Shaker is the level I find the best to fit my case) and some days in which no matter how much I walked it would not convert steps to coins.. it would just say xxxx steps and 0 coins.. which is the case now... 3k steps & 0.61 coins.. gosh this is lame... not to mention that two phones used for the same walk NEVER convert the same amount of coins.. ridiculous.
title: Gave this a second chance and it failed again

review: I like this app. I think the concept is brilliant to try to find a fun way to get people out and moving. People complain about the wonky steps, which I‚Äôve experienced a bit of. But mostly when reading the reviews I‚Äôm shocked by the amount of people who claim the prizes are unattainable and it would take 5 years to get to some of the higher ones.... This is a free app! The prizes should be incredibly hard to reach. If anyone knows of any free apps where I can reach a $1000 in 3-6 months please let me know. For the time being I‚Äôm going to enjoy a few cents or dollars here or there.
title: Let‚Äôs be honest

review: So I walk a lot, and I thought why not get an app that also pays to walk. Sounds cool in theory. Except one problem. I have this huge house and neighborhood I walk all the time, kids I‚Äôm constantly running after and taking places. I roughly walk 20,000 steps a day. So hitting the bare minimum of 5,000 should be the easiest thing ever. So want to know my problem, by the end of the day when I feel like I can‚Äôt walk anymore, I check in with this app that has been running in my background all day and draining my battery to the bone, it‚Äôs only counted around 1,700 steps! That‚Äôs just a waste of my time and and why bother with it!!! You guys will end up sued if you don‚Äôt figure out how to fix that. Absolutely ridiculous! I‚Äôm definitely deleting the app and never bothering with it again. Thanks for wasting my time! ü§¨ü§¨ü§¨

title: It‚Äôs a really good app!! One thing though..

title: it‚Äôs okay!

review:
Its great to see an app that does this. Honestly, who can complain? You download the app, set it up, give it access to you gps location and whatever apps it needs to count more steps. Kinda invasive on that part, though. The payout in sweatcoins isn‚Äôt the best ration at the current version of app.

Most steps I have gotten counted was 2259 verified steps and earned only 2.14 sweatcoins on a day the app counted 10,000+ steps. Algorithm needs heavily adjusted on this part. I compare the steps the app does with a high priced step-counter and they are different but not far off from each other. 

Long term goals say 20k sweatcoins, 24 mos of steps and invites but how many invites? Be nice to know that aspect so we can work harder getting people to join in on this.

As far as making purchases, at the present time, nothing has really caught my attention in wanted to test. Most of the items are subscription based. Need to set it up where a featured item/company is weekly but then need 2-3 spots for daily change-outs

review:

review:
I see no value to this app. First, most people with a phone that could use this app would have a built in step tracker that tracks every type of step you take.

Second, the app has no valuable rewards. The only rewards I have ever seen are the first month of one of the cheap awful subscription ship to your door plans for free. Then it would automatically subscribe you so that company can charge you for the next month before you realize what happened. If you want a month free from any of those subscription plans just go directly to their site and they will give it to you without you earning anything. 

This app is just a giant promotion for subscription services and a huge waste of time and battery power.

title: Pointless

I‚Äôve been using the app for months now, regularly hit the daily free max so I‚Äôm well over 1,000 points, and it got that high because there is nothing interesting to trade them for. If you‚Äôre just trying to encourage yourself to walk more, I implore you to do it with a different app. There are many others with actual rewards.

1. You need to be able to use it inside. I live in a climate where it‚Äôs winter half the year. I work indoors where I walk a bit. So my entire day when it‚Äôs my cold time of year, I get a couple hundred steps that count because they‚Äôre outside. When really I‚Äôm walking 7,000+ steps inside a day. So it‚Äôs useless to me.
2. The money you get just isn‚Äôt worth it. You‚Äôd have to get $10 every single day for a year, just to get a gift card. One prize. Per year. You win one good thing. Per year.  I‚Äôd rather save the space on my phone and buy my own gift card.

title: Waste of Time

review:
i‚Äôve been using this app for almost 2 years, and there are definitely some pros and cons, so i will list them here.
pros:
-you can donate to organizations 
-you can see how many steps you‚Äôve taken
-you can convert sweatcoins into actual cash

cons:
-in the two years that i‚Äôve used this app, i have 302K steps in total. however, i only have 286 sweatcoins.
-the cash rewards on sweatcoin aren‚Äôt that great
-the whole ‚Äòinvite 20 friends and get 20 cash in your paypal‚Äô is bull. i invited 25 and got nothing.
-you get a single sweatcoin every 1,000 steps. 
-to get 20,000 sweatcoins, you need to take 20 million steps. really???

overall i think this app is great for fun. but to actually make money off of it is ridiculous. there is no way (unless you spend like, 10 years, and even then probably not) you can make actual good money on this, so i don‚Äôt understand why that is one of their main advertisements. their slogan is literally ‚Äúit pays to walk‚Äù but you have to take 20 million steps to make 1,000 dollars? nah.
title: good but not for actually making money

review: It‚Äôs a really neat idea and I was excited when I first learned about it because I walk a lot. You (developers) are upfront when you say that the app will not count all of your steps. I appreciate that. It doesn‚Äôt calculate what you feel it does ( Half), it‚Äôs closer to a third of the steps. Also the app closes on its own almost daily which results in the loss of steps. My Apple Watch counts my steps and I‚Äôll go to check Sweatcoin to see what I‚Äôve earned and it won‚Äôt even be open. I do not shut my phone off at night, and I update the app pretty regularly. ü§∑üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I will continue to work with the app but hope to see some major changes soon. Thank you for a neat idea.
title: I like the idea...but

review:
This is an update to my last review which I posted in April 2018.

With this past update the conversion rate is insane! Sorry to say I'm uninstalling the app today.
I hate that I'm going to loose the 700 coins I've earned. But say-la-vee!
I've had the app for almost a year. According to the description in the item page, "with 10,000 a day" goal
(and I do walk at least 10,000 steps at least 5 days a week)
I should have close to 3000 coins, if not more. 700 coins is far from the expected total for a year.

App was updated yesterday, today I walked over 10,000 steps, it converted 214 which equals .13
I've had the app for quite a while now, (I even had the upgrade to the higher level) hoping they would come up with a good algorithm to stop the cheating, but it's just been getting worse. A couple of updates ago I thought it was getting better, a couple times I hit the max and was actually loosing coins because I needed to upgrade. But it wasn't constant. Couple days in a row I would hit max, and then a couple days in a row it would barely convert any. I walk the same about every day. Very disappointed in how the programmers are updating.

title: Disappointed

review: I was really excited about this, I mean it‚Äôs a great idea! Getting money for exercising seems like a win win right? However you begin to realize that this company can‚Äôt just give away money for free. This isn‚Äôt a walk and get paid thing. You get ‚Äúcoins‚Äù, a form of virtual currency, which you trade in for prizes, not actual money. And some of the trades are really neat like a television or an iPhone, but the amount of coins you need in so high it‚Äôs virtually unattainable. The smaller prizes are subscription based. You give five coins to get a subscription discount, but either way you need to provide credit card information, and the thing isn‚Äôt even totally paid for. I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs great for some people but it‚Äôs really a missed opportunity more than anything and highly disappointing.
title: Disappointing

review:
The app works great for the most part, but there are some adjustments I believe that should be made.

1) This may seem small to some, but when I close out of the app or turn my phone off, I receive a notification that basically threatens me that I will lose Sweatcoins, and when I reopen the app the same exact message shows up EVERY TIME claiming that it lost some steps. I feel as though I should be able to turn those off.

2) I believe the app should convert the Sweatcoins to tell you what the currency would be for your country (for me it‚Äôs USD$).

3) I understand that as of right now, Sweatcoins aren‚Äôt worth REAL money for exchange, but I wish it were easier to get the earned money from the SC. This isn‚Äôt a big issue for me, however. Just a thought.

4) Lastly, I think the app should track and generate indoor steps as well as outdoor steps. Many people are indoors a lot, depending on the job or if they‚Äôre a student. It‚Äôs hard to really get those steps in when they only count for steps taken outside.

title: sweatcoin

review: I was getting adds all over my social media saying, ‚ÄúI got this on Sweat Coin!‚Äù and ‚ÄúThis app pays you to walk!‚Äù. title: Outstanding

review:
So I enjoy this app for what it is. I appreciate what they are trying to do with it, and that the app needs to stay open in the background in order to count your steps.

However, because the app never closes itself and stays active all the time, updates from the app store cannot run the way they normally would. You have to force close the app to remove it from memory, to allow the app store update to run. And when you do this, you get all the notifications from the app about not closing it. It's not gonna stop me from using the app, but it is annoying.
title: Great app, with one annoyance

review:
It does take a while to accrue Sweatcoins. But it is free. So are you really in that big a hurry? Obviously they are not going to just give you cash for walking. They have to make money to run the app so they make deals with brands, a lot of the time it is weird stuff, but just keep an eye on it every day when you do your free  Daily Reward. I have gotten free trials of two great meditation apps and a pair of yoga pants. I did have to pay $10 shipping for $75 yoga pants. 

TLDR if you don‚Äôt mind it tracking your every move and you are a patient person you might like it.
title: Slow but free

To those of you trying to decide whether or not to get it ‚Ä¶ just download it, pay the $25 annual membership, and just put away the app and don‚Äôt look at it.  Then go in and shop!

developerResponse:
{'id': 16849539, 'body': "Thank you for your review here.
Please know that we never sell any data to any third parties and never will. You can read up on our privacy policy on our website or via the app for more information there...
Regarding the prizes, we work hard to add new offers in all the time, but it can be challenging (especially in these hard times) for brands to agree to give away products for free for steps alone -- however, we are working hard to add new offers all the time!

In the meantime, we hope to add more things into the app all the time and appreciate your feedback here.
Team Sweatcoin", 'modified': '2020-07-24T11:38:53Z'}
review:
Here‚Äôs how it works: you get ‚ÄúSweatcoins‚Äù for every step you take and can theoretically trade them in for prizes. In exchange the app tracks you everywhere you go and sells that data to companies. 

The thing is, you‚Äôre not really getting anything for that data. The prizes you can use your sweatcoins to purchase are mostly things like 50% a subscription to a fitness account. Or a free month trial that requires you to sign up for a membership first. If you walk 20 miles a day for several years you might be able to win a free trip, but every piece of content that you make on that trip (every photo, video, Instagram, etc.) belongs solely to sweatcoin. 

I think having our every move tracked is worth a little more than that.
title: Not Worth Giving Away Your Data

review:
Why bother allowing another app to track your movements and mine your very personal and valuable information when their virtual shop is always ‚ÄúSOLD OUT‚Äù of anything worth purchasing with the sweat coins you earn from your mobility?!  

Undoubtedly, the more coins you stack correlates with your increased physical activity (and more unique locations). Sweat coin bundles those details and hawks them off to the highest bidder for A LOT of COIN! Worth far more than a sweat coin which actual value hovers around a fraction of one cent. 

At fist I thought the sold out gift shop was an isolated incident. Alas it was not.  Safeguard your personal privacy and save your sweat and coins for something better.

title: Gift card

review:
Ok, this inevitably sounds like its too good to be true.

It is. Allow me to don my tinfoil hat for a moment.

Ok, so the idea is creating ‚Äúsweatcoins‚Äù through walking actual distances and your steps which are hyped to someday be actual currency. Since the only use for these coins are in their store, you would think you would some cool stuff there.

In reality, you are providing data on your GPS whereabouts and travels. For what you may ask? For shopping for worthless ‚Äúdiscounts‚Äù on new products that you can probably just get with a google search. I bought a snacknation discount that expired at midnight. I was upset when it expired but not as upset as when i was presented with an ad for the same deal. Are they just ‚Äúselling us‚Äù first time user coupons for new products? Basically. 

Once I realized this, the whole concept is really starting to concern me. I‚Äôm going to go ahead and say it, there are no plans for turning this into a crypto currency.  We are almost literally hamsters on a wheel chasing an unobtainable piece of cheese. But what is the wheel powering? 

The cake is a lie.
title: BE CAUTIOUS. The cake is a lie.

review:
So I work outside, and I walk, ALOT. Some days 30-40,000 steps and I‚Äôm on the highest tier available. I‚Äôve had this app running in the background the entire time. 

I have 1,300 sweat coins. After 2 YEARS. The collection algorithm is WAY off. Some days my phone says I walk 30,000 steps and I get credited for only 4,000. My GPS is enabled, the app is running in the background, I am walking OUTSIDE. So how does this constantly happen?

I‚Äôve been saving my coins for something at least somewhat worthwhile and there is either rewards that are ‚Äúfree trials‚Äù that you pay coins for. Or they are so astronomically overpriced you couldn‚Äôt ever hope of achieving enough coins.

In a perfect scenario you should be able to get enough coins for the $1,000 PayPal reward after 5 years. Right. If they actually calculated your steps correctly MAYBE. But at this rate it‚Äôll take me 10 years of them collecting my usage to make $1,000.

And like I said, I don‚Äôt walk casually, my full time job requires me to walk in excess.

This app is incredibly misleading, has very poor rewards for effort, and is not accurate in the slightest.

I used to live where it was much colder and I know the mall opened up early specifically for ‚Äúmall walkers‚Äù ‚Äî people who wanted to exercise but didn‚Äôt want to be outdoors. This restriction is ridiculous and poorly thought out in regards to non-ideal outside environments.
title: Needs to Consider the Indoors

review: Okay, so this app sounds great right away. However, all the developer is likely doing is retrieving some personal information along with quite a few location services from its users and giving us a very low payout. Not only does the app only count steps taken outside but the transfer rate of its currency is awful. 1 US dollar is worth about 1050 sweat coins. So, if you want that big prize of 1000 dollars (as an airlines reward or PayPal, etc.) you would have to take 21,000,000 steps. Or roughly 9,300 miles of walking. That would take a lot of time and would likely not happen for the average person, meanwhile, the developers are getting all the information they want to sell.
